author: Zoey
text: This was recommended to me by youtube today after I watched a few of your videos. I live in the UK and have weekly food waste and paper waste disposal, bi-weekly large green bins Canada style along with mixed recycling black bin. So I put all the bins out this Monday on collection day in a row and for some reason was the only house on the street not to have their food waste and paper recycling collected. I checked the food waste bin like "Huh maybe this was emptied." only to open it and be greeted with a writhing ocean of maggots at the bottom in my food waste. Actually vile. The imagine is going to haunt me and live rent free in my head for weeks if not months. I wish we had collections like this but I am stuck in shitty UK suburbia, much more walkable and accessible than North American suburbs but still terribly lonely and now I am discovering inefficient in so many other ways :D

author: Polas Ragge
text:
We in switzerland have like, a mix.

Trash like Oil, plastic, PET, Glass (brown green and white), Aluminium are all getting thrown away in a small area (in my town its right next to my old school) where there are underground Containers like amsterdam has. But your paper/household/iron/electrical/other stuff is going right infornt of your house in bags, we can use tradh containers but there are only for green stuff and food, other stufd like cardboatd and just getting outside.

Everthing has itw own day in the week.
Every 2 days, household trash like food etc. Are getting collected by those trash trucks.
Cardboard every 3 days
Green every friday
And etc.
Things like cardboard are only allowed to be outside, 1-2 days before their pickup date.
Oh and if someone asks how were battleing against racoons? Well, first off we have little of them, second off we litteraly put 10$ locks on the containers and they cant get opened when theyre full.
Mind you, i live in a block with 15 Apartments, atleast 31 people.

Unless they come at 2 PM because ?????????
Anyway.

We put out our garbage from 8 PM to 1 AM depending when we are ready to do so, the prior evening.
It's also like yours was in that it's regular garbo one week, garbo and recycling the 2nd week. It's infuriating and piles the shit up INSIDE our apartment because...yeah.

author: dmisso42
text:
Garbage day is a uniquely Inner Urban problem.
I live in what is called a suburb in Australia.
I have a weekly garbage collection and an alternating fortnightly recycle and "green waste" collection. (Green waste is garden clipping, pruning and (for some people) leaves).
If I had my druthers, charges for garbage would be calculated on weight.
I don't think it would be beyond our ingenuity to fit a weighing machine calculator connected to a system that attributed your individual reading to your rates .
As a "hermit" I put out my refuse bine about once every two months. My recycle bin (because I'm a bottle a day lush) goes out once a month.
I' like to a system that charges you a collection charge related to your output.

author: dmisso42

author: Moo-sheep
text: You complain about the raccoons, but at least you get a cute animal making the mess. We get seagulls, and until we had underground containers here in The Hague, the seagulls would know the garbage schedule better than the humans living in the city. On the evening before garbage collection day in my neighbourhood, the seagulls would gather on the roofs in anticipation for the buffet that the humans would willingly offer them, putting out their garbage bags, which would invariably be ripped apart and their contents strewn all across the street and the sidewalk. If it was particularly windy, the trash would even get blown into gardens and parklands. And the screeching of those seagulls isn't cute. It sounds like crackheads having loud sex with each other. Next time you see a raccoon, pet them, and be thankful you have them in your trashbin and not a seagull.

author: Aaron Passmore
text: he makes it sound neat but in reality it's a major downgrade to quality of life. This video is akin to admiring how much more difficult your life was made by government. He has to carry every single bag 50 meters, or more, to throw it away. I bet it's more like 100 meters each time, and I bet those bags pile up at the front door because no one wants to take them. So let's look at ten bags. That's 1,000 meters he's carried them. On the other hand, I have to carry each bag 6 meters to the bin. Once a week I push that bin another 6 meters to the curb. That's ten bags for a total of 66 meters compared to his 1km of hard labor. I'll keep the bins and trucks thank you very much.

author: mediocre man
text:
Stupid concept.
• You need to dig a hole in the street.
• You have a hole in the street. Holes cannot be moved easily, should the need arise.
• What if something gets in that is not supposed to get in? Have fun getting this out without major headache.

In Vienna, there are big containers, 770L or 1100L, usually one or two stand next to each other, and you have them in each neighbourhood. This is where you depose of your household's trash, and the city comes to have them emptied regularly. Since there are no raccoons in Central Europe, I do not know what damage they could do (I suppose none, for those containers are damn heavy, with massive lids), but never have I seen wild animals mess them up. And the system is way cheaper and more flexible than the system in Amsterdam.

author: jxdigital
text:
Well, I also live in The Netherlands and I hate these underground bins. At least te ones they use in my town. They are nice in theory, but in reality I see them getting clogged/broken as often as every week, but usually every 14 days. When it's clogged, lot's of trash is piling up around them, because people have no where else to put their garbage bags. Then there's the wind, which blows the trash all over the streets around the underground bins. The other BIG downside: it takes the trucks a VERY long time to unload them. It may be fun to watch like the video suggests, but in reality it's often like 5-10 minutes of very high early morning noise pollution if you're unlucky enough to live nearby. It's a very tedious non-automated process that, again, takes ages.

In our town we have ones that are electronically opened with a card. How often it's clogged, depends on the model/version, but even with the newer ones we have it happens a lot (again, at least once every 14 days). The video shows bins that don't have these electronic card, maybe those are more reliable.

All in all, they really need to improve upon their design, allow for a bigger opening, fool-proof system that doesn't clog, and is much faster to unload.

BTW, they only use them in the town centers in The Netherlands, outside of the city center everyone still has a regular big garbage bin of their own.

author: Jurgis Sinkevičius
text:
During soviet times, we knew beforehand a general time when garbage truck would arrive. A few minutes before, we would open our flat's door and wait to hear it honking. After a honk, there would be ~5 minutes to get the trash from you flat to the garbage truck, or you wait for another week.
An upside for that, however, was the fact that we didn't need garbage bags - we would just use a bucket, we would empty it into the truck, wash it if it smelled, and that's it - so less single-use plastics for the nature.

Perhaps it is just the stubbornness of expectation, but I just find it more convenient to pop into my garage or around the corner of the building with my 60-liter bag and toss it, and don't mind the weekly trash collection and fortnightly recycling collection. De gustibus non disputandum est, I suppose.

author: holyhyrax
text:
2 things.

1. You say there is no garbage day , but then say the bins are emptied on schedule. Ummm.....thats basically the same thing as "garbage day"
2. So while you have to walk probably 50 yards every day....or multiple times a day to find a recycle bin....all I need to do is open up by kitchen door to the outside and my recycle bin is right there. And I can fill it up with small or very large recyclable items like packing boxes. I don't have to worry about anything fitting into some public receptacle. And then, once a week, on a schedule, i walk the bin to the sidewalk. It's really not a big deal. How can someone forget and then have to wait for another week?

author: segpasta
text:
Everything this guy talks abouy being so abnormal for you americans, is pretty common here where I live, in Sweden.

I didn't know america had all of these weird things even though Ive been there once.

We have everything they have in Netherlands here in Sweden. Our neughbours, Finland, Denmark and Norway do aswell.

I can't speak for other European countries as Ive just not experienced enough to see it.

But its so fascinating to see an american be in awe over something so normal and every day life here in Sweden.

America has one thing though and thata big V8: engines and cheap gas. Yes, if you thougt your gas was expensive then take a look at what a gallon in Sweden buys you.

Last time I went to fill up my car, which is 30 liters btw, I payed 650kr.

That is, 7.9 gallons for you americans btw. (Standard for a small car here in Europe)

So lets count. 650 kr / 7.9 = 82 kr for 1 gallon.

82 kr is converted, with todays Exchange metric 05/23/2022 at 13:10 into US dollars: 8.35$

Its unironically 8.35$ A FUCKING GALLON. Lmao. So don't think europe got everything that was good, because you guys still have affordable gas and diesel. Im not even gonna talk about the Diesel-price because its actually even more expensive...

Lesson: its all about perspective and what you focus on in the moment, when you say "this place is better" than something else.

All of the containers are being emptied every night (usually between 2am - 4am, so we don't see or hear them) I always thought this is the normal and all of the world does it like this.

Every bin is collected on a different day of the week and in different periods (eg. residual every week, paper every two, etc.). You could imagine how I hate Garbage day even more. It`s just annoying + calendar organization work.

author: Sasparilla Sassafras
text: This is not the case in most other places outside of the big cities in the Netherlands. If you live in a smaller city or in a rural area, you still have garbage day and those large bins animals can get into, in fact there’s a calendar for the different days of the month where different types of garbage are picked up (green, paper, restafval or basically generic trash, and in some places plastic separately too).

author: Thomas Joosten
text: I should note here that this isn't exactly how it works everywhere in the Netherlands. Here in my small city in the province of Limburg we still have bins and garbage trucks going down the streets on specific days. It's not like that's rare, a lot of places still have that system. However, I do think the majority of places have these sorts of communal bins for glass; there is one very close to my house that we can just drop the glass into. There are also big bins next to it for like, clothing and the like as well I think. I will say, there are also general bins in our city center that work kind of similar, but those are a bit smaller and are clearly not intended for household garbage, more to keep the city clean. Still though, way better than the USA.

author: Robert Berryman
text:
Ah yes, Garbage Day! First, the magic of Garbage Eve, when all good boys and girls are scurrying about collecting unwanted items, wrapping them up en masse in festive white and black plastic bags, to offer up to the patron of unwanted junk and refuse, Saint de Tritus. Then the next day Saint de Tritus blesses us all with the Tournament of Trash Parade, where his elves, disguised as physically fit humans, collect the offerings and make them all disappear, away down the street.

At least, that was the story we made up when we were kids, to poke a little fun at Christmas and pass the boredom of hauling garbage out to the curb.

author: Slugbunny
text: We use the same system, except it's by building. The containers are monitored for fill level, so if the scheduled pickup is too late, they get picked up sooner. It's great! ❤

Then on Wednesday, maintenance lines up the bins for the trash truck. Though I do wonder what happens when I throw a bag down the chute when the bin isn't there to catch it, glad I don't have that job. Its still a flawed system, but its easier on me and they get paid at least.

author: Johan Liebert
text:
In Finland I've never even thought about this. Houses just have the green bins outside (although not on the sidewalk that's just insane you keep them on your own property next to the driveway). I guess we don't have any wildlife that would attack bins though because I've never had anything like that happen, or even heard or seen it happen to anyone else.

Generally people just take the bin bags from inside to the bigger green bin outside, and don't even think about when they're picked up. I know I have no idea which day it is, but it's often enough that the bin is never overflowing.

That said I think basically all apartment buildings have underground bins like these, and have had them for as long as I can remember.

author: Stephen Bell

author: Walkable Cities
text: In the UK we have the same system as in Canada and most places, it means that you have to keep your rubbish for up to 2 weeks (the council collects recycling every week and rubbish every fortnight) and wherever you keep your bins often gets full of bin juice and maggots, and while we don't have any trash (or rather, rubbish) pandas, we've got foxes to tear up the bins and it stinks on bin day, especially in summer. If I got a penny every time I saw bins torn up, with rubbish strewn across the road I'd be living a mansion in central London with a Ferrari, eating caviar for breakfast lunch and dinner

author: Worm Worm
text:
It’s important to recognise that Amsterdam and many other “innovative” European cities are geographically much smaller than cities in other parts of the world, and thus it is much harder to justify infrastructure changes like this when it will cost so much more (and our governments generally hate the gays and deny climate change and you get the idea). I’m not saying it’s not a good idea and that I wouldn’t implement if I had the choice, it’s just that I don’t make decisions, the government does, and they don’t like to spend that much money.

On top of that, many of these European cities like Amsterdam are high value tourist destinations and thus make a lot of money off of tourism, and also have more reason to clean up the streets on account of rubbish turning away that sweet sweet tourist revenue. I’m simply saying this because I can’t imagine this ever being implemented where I live in Brisbane, because unlike Amsterdam which is about 220 square kilometres of civil responsibility, Brisbane is 15,000. And I don’t exactly think Brisbane is really up there in terms of “historically valuable, beautiful architecture, so much culture” tourist destinations.

Personally I hate the urban sprawl of Australian cities and think that small, dense, self governing communities are superior in so many ways, but my point is that there’s a reason Amsterdam has the ability to make all these revolutionary civil decisions.

author: Massimo Neri
text: You completely missed the point, here. We always had big communal bins at the end of the street pretty much everywhere in Europe (some of them underground and some of them above the ground). In recent years, governments and local authorities have shifted to small private bins. Small bins encourage recycling. The volume of the bin is your weekly quota of trash and if you exceed it you have to store the trash somewhere else. Moreover, countries like Italy are starting to experiment with very strict quotas: pretty much everything has to be recycled and you have few bags *per year* of unrecyclable trash. If you recycle too little, you'll consume all your quota and have to call the council to get the mixed trash taken (and pay for the service). All of this starts with small and private bins for each household.

author: fr89k
text: In Munich, we also have a similar system and it sucks hard. The reasons are: 1) The containers have a size, so that they are almost guaranteed full, when the garbage truck comes. The result is that in weeks where people have lots of trash (by coincidence), the containers are massively overflowing. Then you can either be a dick and pour your garbage also besides the container or take it back home - or as I also did once, throw the plastic waste into the container for residual waste. After all a lot of plastics is not recyclable anyways. However, I think due to this the plastic recycling percentage is very low in Munich. 2) I don't have my plastic waste in bags, because it's stupid to buy and use bags only to throw them away. I have my plastic waste in a plastic box. However, when it's windy outside, it's virtually impossible to go to the container with the box without some light plastic being blown away. Even if you used a lid, you still get the problem once you open the box to empty it into the container. Also, due to the small hole in the container, I have to touch each and every item again and potentially have dirty stinky finger afterwards. In the city where I lived before, we had 1100l containers that could be fully opened. There, I can just open it and pour everything from the box into the container without touching it. If there is some wind shielding around, this even works nicely on windy days... I am not saying that the system is generally useless, but in Munich the implementation is just shit...

author: Daniel Malinen
text:
How has Amsterdam solved the problem of different costs for rubbish bins? For example, maintaining and emptying rubbish bins costs what it means to lose money, so how is it dealt with?

In Finland, for money saving, rubbish bins have been outsourced to private companies from which cities then rent rubbish bins for a limited period of time. Often only for the summer. In winter, rubbish bins are collected in warehouses and not brought back until late spring. Therefore, in the winter, people are encouraged to carry their own rubbish home instead of dropping the rubbish on the street. It doesn’t work perfectly, but it gets cheaper than keep public rubbish bins all year round. It has also been suggested that in the future, rubbish bins will operate like vending machines, so that the cap of the bin will only open by paying. This would further reduce the cost of rubbish bins.

author: Stumbling Into Comedy
text:
There was a mind-boggling, nonsensical, inefficient, dystopian weekly routine where I used to live:
1. Everyone puts their bins out on the street.
2. Wind blows open the flimsy bin lids or knocks the bins over, spilling trash all over the street.
3. Animals tear open bin bags, letting trash pour out onto the street.
4. Wind blows the trash all over the place, mixing it all up so that no one can tell whose trash it is and no one wants to take responsibility any more.
5. The city street sweeper comes round to clear up all the mess.
6. Repeat

author: SpaghettiTF2
text:
I personally don't feel any negativity towards the bin system in Toronto as it is something that takes 2 minutes a week which you can easily just slot that time whenever you leave and come back from work. As for the raccoons my area used to have a lot but I usually just left a brick on top of it and they left it alone. The wheels on the bins I felt were big and good at going up and down steps. When they were emptied they were very light and easy to take up and downs steps and you could basically carry it just trying to drag it up steps because of the weight. A huge flaw with the system however was the weekly alternating schedule of garbage and recycling pickup as if you missed a garbage day you'd have to wait 2 weeks. Something similar happened where one of the garbage bags was wedged into the bottom therefore not being emptied and made us have an extra bag of garbage laying around for 2 weeks in the bin.
A question: In Amsterdam do they use dumpsters for apartments and other residential buildings in a similar way that Toronto does it?

author: Bob Smith
text:
Looks really expensive to implement, just to save you the trouble of wheeling your garbage out to the curb, once a week. Plus, there's the issue of how far apart they place these. I can just imagine them putting in one per neighborhood, and then having to walk a mile to empty your garbage.

Also, these recepticals look pretty complex with a lot of moving parts and electronics. What happens when one breaks down? Just throw your garbage on the street?

This is the kind of idea that sounds like a good idea on paper, but would be horrible to implement. It may work in Amsterdam, but it would be a huge failure, in America, with the beaurocrats running it.

author: Chris Davies
text:
If we did this in New Zealand people would simply take their bags of garbage to a local park, and chuck them there. Or, they'd carry the bag to within 2 metres of the proper receptacle, and dump it on the ground close to it.

What a wonderfully backward modern INconvenience you have invented!

Look, here's what science, progress, and increasing wealth is supposed to achieve: MORE convenience. Not LESS!
I see absolutely no advantage to city dwellers in this system, and would not want it implemented here. I have three bins, one small one for green waste, one medium sized for landfill, and one large for recycling.

The green waste bin is collected each week, and the other two on alternating weeks. It's a tremendous system, which still gets abused by our lazy, careless, and stupid citizens. :P

author: Kaito Gillscale
text: I’d love to see NYC adopt a streamlined version of this. Like…say…a conveyor system underground like how we have underground subway tunnels all over the city. Reason I say this is because NYC traffic is insane, and between the buses and taxis that already flood the streets amongst the regular 9-5’ers and tourists…garbage trucks take up a lot of space and only add to the pile-ups. NYC also has a really bad littering problem because in NYC it’s very common to overflow your can and just try to stuff it in because of how many people are in one area. A system like this, but given extra accommodations like a compactor that webs up the square of compacted trash before sending it to a processing plant underground could be instrumental in cleaning up the streets and limiting unneeded traffic clutter. NYC is always under construction, so it wouldn’t be crazy to add this to the mix.

author: NiagaraWarrior
text:
This is a pretty interesting video, this system would be pretty interesting to use within the Toronto / GTA area for sure.

As a Canadian i can appreciate the annoyance of carrying your garbage bin to the street, however i've never met anyone who's carried those bins inside their homes, since they are wheeled bins and typically left outside.
Because they have latches that prevent animals from getting in they can be left outside usually, but clearly certain circumstances require them to be brought in.

Regarding Raccoons, its a general rule of thumb to:
a) rinse your food containers / garbage to reduce attractiveness to animals.
(also since recycling and garbage pickups alternate per week, it prevents the trash from stinking up the bins and attracting flies
b) Never leave the bins or the blue boxes at the curb for pick up until the morning of pickup, it prevents night time predators from spending all night figuring out how to get into your bin.
c) When Panda's figure out how to open the latch to the garbage a fool proof method to keep it closed is to put something heavy on top of it, like a paver stone, OR drill a hole in the latch and put a padlock through it.

author: Matthew Hill
text:
We here in New Jersey have three garbage days a week. Regular trash is picked up on Mondays and Thursdays, and recyclables (paper/bottles/cans/glass) are picked up on Wednesdays. Other recyclables (e.g. computers, TVs, other appliances) are "by appointment"--you call, tell them what you have, and they come and take it the next morning.

So, yeah, if you open a window, there's always a garbage truck driving by. Except Tuesdays. Which is the street cleaner...

author: Michael Lawson
text: That story about the russians using a pencil in space is a myth. Nor did NASA spend millions developing a pen to write in space. First, a pencil is forbidden in space, due to the graphite which can cause an explosion in the pure oxygen atmosphere of a space capsule. Both countries used grease pencils.

author: iaadsi
text:
Our neighborhood in Prague replaced regular above ground dumpsters with these a few years ago. It wasn't accepted well. The underground dumpsters have receptacles smaller than common garbage bags, so you need to cram your garbage into it with force. Sometimes bags burst, so these hightech underground dumpsters are surrounded by heaps of rotting trash that didn't fit in.

The old dumpsters had a sliding lid that opened to a 1 by 1.5 meter opening, you could throw in a 100 liter bag once a week. Now we need to use smaller bags (30-40 liter) and go more often (so more plastic bags, more time spent).

The old dumpsters could be picked up and emptied by the garbage truck inside of 20 seconds. The underground one needs a crane and a crew of men guiding it with rods, and it takes 1-2 minutes each. Every Tuesday morning is a race to beat the garbage truck, because it clogs the one-way street for 20+ minutes.

author: Thunderhawk51
text:
For someone who's been living his whole life in a country like Finland, that feels beyond absurd. Granted, I never lived in a big city and we don't have raccoons here. But in towns/cities, you don't have your own garbage bin. The neighborhood or the building you live in will have them and you don't have to worry about them. And there are dedicated recycling areas around the city.

Another thing I'd like to mention is that we get money when we return the bottles and cans back to the shops. 0.15€ from cans 0,10€/0,20€/0,40€ from bottles. That amount is already included in the product price, but we can get it back. There are machines in the shops that you put them in and it gives you a ticket that you can turn into money or use it to buy something. The bottles and cans are then recycled and reused. I'm quite interested which other countries have this kind of a system in use? I know Sweden does at least.

author: Katerina Leonova
text:
I live in Moscow, Russia and I have never heard of garbage day. I have also never seen those green garbage cans. Instead, we have these huge garbage containers outside which we throw our trash into. Kinda like in Amsterdam, except not underground and no recycling (even when there is a place for that, it's hard to say how much is actually recycled). Then these containers are emptied out every day or almost every day depending on the place. In the past we also had garbage chutes to which you had access on every floor of the building. You would basically throw your trash there and it would travel to the container. Now there are almost no places that have them working, but still.
Plus we have this tradition that if you are throwing away some furniture or books you can just leave them outside the container and someone else might take them.
Anyway, it was really interesting to learn how you take out your trash in other countries :) I never thought that it could be so different!

author: Dino
text:
Oh yeah, they used this idea for parks in Abbotsford BC.
It was utilized along with a few other scams as a work-around to bust the civil worker's unions.

Rather than having several garbage cans throughout the parks, they have only one near the entrance and garbage and bags of dog waste tends not to make it into the bin. It gets to be a disgusting, stinking mess during the summer, especially when the underground bin is over full and it takes a week for the company to be scheduled to empty it with their very expensive crane service.

After breaking these unions, the city now spends more for the same results given the amount of workers it takes now to both keep up the parks and the patrols of ticket writers plus the revenue influx for the initial conversion.

Perhaps it works if you do it for the 'right reasons' and you have the people buy-in first but I think the main difference here is the availability to the user so inconvenience does not become an issue.

And I am pretty sure that its the same in Netherlands. I doubt in some smaller villages or towns there will be underground containers. For more than one practical reason.

author: Debbie Henri
text:
It's so nice that the Dutch are willing to co-operate with such schemes. The streets (what we saw of them), do look clean, so evidently most people are taking the trouble to adapt and consign their rubbish to these bins.

However, this would not work in Britain at all. I believe too many of my fellow countrymen would deliberately continue to dump their rubbish outside their gates (or outside someone else's) - as a protest against the idea that they have to go to 'any' extra effort to keep their streets tidy.
It's a shame, because this really is a good idea and probably saves Dutch local councils money in the long term - money which can then go to other public projects.

author: Not Loki
text:
This makes sense in cities, especially if you have less rain and proper infrastructure for water dissipation. Another one I saw in my country was on hydraulics. The truck would connect to the top feeder and raise the whole platform while in the enclosure you had a classic larger bin (like the ones you see in American movies behind a restaurant for example).

The technology is not amazing, but the reason why it's not being done here in the UK for example, is due to how many people per square km you have. It would make no sense to have one of these just to service 20 households or so due to most of the country living in houses instead of apartment buildings. Also would not justify the cost of building and maintaining them. The underground is often used for other stuff, like electrical and gas pipes, not to mention the drainage system. Finding a spot for these would be a challenge when most space that does not have a building on it, is privately owned.

author: Tesla Falcon
text:
NASA pen / pencil story is missing a few key parts to the story.
1) NASA also used pencils until the SpacePen was finished.
2) NASA made the request and funded it via a private company.
3) After the pen was made & shipped to NASA, additional pens were made and sold commercially as well as the core tech being applied to numerous high-end pens.
4) Pen company made the initial investment & then some through commercial sales & paid NASA back their investment.

author: Pedro Fleck

author: Chris C
text:
I'm always leery of these kinds of mechanical - or worse electrical! - solutions to stuff. Since if it's a moving part, it will fail. Plus the issues with something like this with snow and ice in some climates. Melt water loves to get all up inside moving bits like this and refreeze. Jamming things up, or breaking things when it's forced. And then you're left without a place to put trash until it's repaired/replaced.

I can completely see how it would be worth it despite those concerns, but the concerns still need to be mitigated.

There's even a better system (i'm biased, my research work led me to work with a local company developing systems like that), that those underground containers are connected to the central collection point via pipes, and emptied remotely, when is needed (or when energy is cheap, solar production maxed at noon, for instance):

author: tardis mole
text: The last I heard, these collection points are being trialled in Oxford, England. It's a great idea, in principle, especially in places where the streets are very narrow and the buildings very old and susceptible to traffic vibration. But not so great if you're disabled, have a chronic illness, elderly or can't drive. How do you get your recycling etc to the collection point then? Imagine being a wheelchair user, with your garbage bag on your lap, and it splits half way down the road. The biggest problem we have is sky rats (seagulls).

author: jtland
text: Sadly there are probably some hidden benefits to keeping our stupid bin system. Americans as a whole, we love to buy an absurd amount of cheap crap that breaks and goes in the landfill. In my eyes, one positive is that the size of the garbage bins that each household has, can be a legitimate deterrent to buying more stuff. I have heard my parents actually being up the point of having more garbage/recycling than could be put in the bin this week as a reason to not buy something. I doubt most people actually have this problem especially where it matters with trash since most people I know actually have this problem with recycling. Since our recycling system is so backed up and inefficient, there are indirect incentives to recycle less, like weirdly small recycling bins. A couple of years ago when I was spending my Christmas holiday in Houston, Texas, they actually stopped picking up recycling as a whole around that time since the amount of boxes from the holiday was so immense, they had to pause accepting any more recycling to have their facilities get through what they already had.

author: Sven SP
text:
Well of course it is nice that you can take out your garbage 24/7, but these containers smell as hell, especially with temperatures. The containers that compress the garbage, also press open bags, and all the juices of rotting veggies and meat and diapers will mix. Some of these containers can be smelled from within the homes nearby, or businesses like restaurants.

Then there are all these people walking to the container and, if they are full, just dumping it next to it. The result then is that the guy who wants to empty the container can't do it because he would first need to shuffle all the other garbage away, before he can pull the container out.

I reckon there must be smarter, cheaper ways to solve the same thing. This "improvement" was surely well sold by the industry, but not thought through properly.

author: Alto Burger
text:
It's a nice idea in theory, but here in Australia illegal rubbish dumping is a big problem so I can see a similar system being taken advantage of here. On my regular daily dog walks, I walk past about half a dozen public bins. These bins are near bus stops or are in public parks and are intended for people's lunch wrappers, dog poo etc... However people come down in the middle of the night and cram household waste like televisions, microwaves, old TV cabinets chopped up or even just the excess waste from a big party they couldn't fit in their own bins.
Love the idea... But Dutch people by nature are a lot less selfish than Australians. I've been to The Netherlands several times and have always been taken back by how nice and friendly everyone is. I think this system works because Dutch people tend to care about their community.

author: Joël
text:
Dear Americans:
- No, walking a 100m is not bad for you. Lose some weight if you think that trip is too tiresome.
- Yes, it is amazing we never have to deal with any rodents or raccoons. I know!
- No, it is not convenient to walk for a minute daily at best to empty your garbage.
- No, it is not gross to touch a garbage bag. Remember, you touch that same bag when you put it inside your bins.
- Yes, it is very communistic. The idea of a government that cares about efficiency must be so frightening.
- Yes, it is something you should want. Just because you live in a city or suburban area that is completely broke due to spending more money on asphalt than anything, you can still expect your city to do something as basic as proper garbage disposal.

author: Rik Zegers
text: I really like the video's of "nog Just bikes". But I disagree on this one. This system of underground containers works fine in a dencely populated city as Amsterdam, but not in a less dence populated neighbourhood. Let me explain. I live in a small town called Vaassen in the Netherlands. De municipality wanted to introduce the same system as in Amsterdam. But because Vaassen is less dencely populated as Amsterdam, the locations of the underground containers are further apart. For most people a walk Of 200 -300 m With a garbagebag is not problem. But if you are less able, a walk of 300 m With  a garbagebag is quite a thing. And you have to do this 4-5 Times a week. Rolling out the thrashbin to the edge of the side walk is only weekly routine. If you are less able, a Neighbour is often willing tot help. Bringing trash to a container 4-5 Times a week to a container 300 m away is bigger burden for the Neighbour. So I and most of my fellow citizens in Vaassen prefer the trashbins as we have now.

author: Andre T
text: Progressive or just a pragmatic economic solution for older inner city garbage solution? Many comments point out bulk garage systems in multi-unit living. This solution isn't  ideal when new multi-unit buildings can incorporate bulk garbage solutions more cost effective  and more  convenient. Can't compare this to suburbs. In our city, garbage trucks have highly an automated arm that single driver/operater picks up bins. It is quick and easy. Looking at the effort to remove one underground bin, it didn't look  quick and easy. Also what  is the maintenance costs?? Looks costly. Again looks to work in that application. Sure cost is buried in taxes and other fees. Since costs are buried, feels good to residents and other users.

author: Smash Man
text:
This video is telling half truths. Mainly because this dude has never lived anywhere else besides dense Dutch city centers. Yes these containers are typical if you live in apartment building or in a dense area. However most places do have trash day, the day when you have to wheel out the trash containers, which everyone keeps in their back or front yard, to the designated trash pick up areas.

Many districts in Amsterdam still have trash day especially areas with normal family homes, and not full of shitty over priced apartments that are full off smug expats like this dude in the video. Like many of his videos it's mainly centered around his experience in Amsterdam center.

author: Andrew
text: So you have to carry your garbage bag out of your house down the street and find an empty bin to dump it this includes your recycling and I imagine the compost, as opposed to using your own bin and wheeling it a short distance to the curb. Not only do you control your own waste when placed into your own bin you never over flow it. I imagine using public dumpsters causes people to dump all sorts of excess crap into them Oh but wait the clever Dutch made the bins really difficult to put anything larger than a small bag in the bin causing you to make trips every day. Yea Toronto spent a lot but I bet installing large trash compacting bins underground and then extracting them with a crane to empty them costs a lot more. I'm sorry but I enjoy the freedom of putting my trash into my own bins, my truck comes once a week picks up the garbage and is gone in 20 seconds. Maybe this works in high density living where you would use big dumpsters anyway but not in suburbia.

author: Krew dla Boga Zbrodni
text:
So basically it's nothing new
We had something like this in Poland, we called those bins "Bells" because of their appearance. Garbage trucks were usually multi-purpose trucks with a hook used to bring up and down large containers so they can either transport them to a client or use them to collect recyclables from the bells using the hydraulic crane that the truck was equipped with. The crane had 2 hooks, one was used to lift the bells, and the other, with adjustable chain lenght was used to pull the opening pin out.
At this time these are very rare sight to see, bcs it's much easier and practical to empty out 1,1 bins with standard rear loader trucks or frontloaders

author: JRcat
text: People think this is amazing and the best thing since sliced bread, but it's not. I used to live in a city that had this, and I hated it. First of all, you were really limited in the size of things you could put in there. Anything bigger than a large shoebox and you're out of luck. Secondly, they would fill up pretty quickly. Thirdly, guess what happens when you have people handle machinery which handles garbage? It becomes really disgusting. People end up wearing gloves to touch the thing because it's so gross. Then there's the issue when the thing is full or when the machine breaks. Some people had to walk 50 years with their trash bags, on the public street. When they got to the underground containers and they were full or not working or the bags wouldn't fit, they would just leave them there. The whole area around the trash chute got really gross and smelled horribly and would have a ton of bugs. But by far the worst thing was when the truck would come by to empty the thing. First of all, it's incredibly loud. It would wake up the whole block in the early morning, second, it would spill some of the trash and leak all kinds of garbage fluids, and the smell was the worst, especially in the summer. Sometimes my whole apartment would smell because of it. So no, not a huge fan. I'll take a regular garbage day any day.

author: bagybachi
text:
I lived in Montreal and madrid. And visited many other places. And experienced some of each approaches.
Underground garbage would have its drawbacks in Montreal. At -40 degrees Celsius water would freeze this underground mechanism. 40 cm of snow could also make them unretrievable. My 90 year old parents would not be able to drag the bag 800m from their house (population density isn’t the same in Amsterdam as in North America....just look at the width of your front door!!). And often our sidewalks are walking hazards. You’d find yourself driving your garbage around. And our raccoons would possibly find their way in your underground bunkers.

I’m a big fan of underground 24/7 garbage deposits. But there are many factors to consider, and a one size fits all doesn’t always work.

Hey! we do have things in common, we can now both get stone legally. Some things are good inspiration. Cheers.

(Just watched your follow-up video, man I feel stupid watching this and even more for commenting,... oh wait, there is a “don’t recommend that channel anymore” option in YouTube, hurray!)

text:
This is pretty cool.
I live in the countryside in Ireland, and I have a big garden, so I just throw my scraps to the birds in the morning, burn my cardboard for fuel in the winter, and recycle my recyclables. Also the time necessary to dispose of your recyclable trash is far from reasonable. Living alone I make 100L of recyclable waste per month.(I drink bottled water), and this with a few cardboard boxes...How on earth would it be OK to spend those 2 hours standing there to throw away my trash.
Recyclable containers should have the same door as general waste.

Having grown up in NY European cities always surprise me with their cleanliness. Madrid specifically feels shockingly clean. Especially considering it's a pretty densely inhabited city with a massive metro area.

author: sjakie49
text:
I guess the grass is always greener on the other side. What many people dont tell, is that The Netherlands is extremely limited in many ways, such as not being able to do things your own way. Would you like to do some outdoor wild camping? Nope, its forbidden. Would you like to Housing expenses are also very high when it comes to rent/price per square meter. Getting permits to personalize or expand your house is also almost impossible. Cars + cartax + petrol is also unpayable. Like, the cars are twice the price of germany's equivalents, even when we are huge trade partners and neighbours. Oh and culturally, people are now making a big fuss out of irrelevant things. I will not start about taxes... if you work hard and succeed, the Dutch tax authority will pick you clean for sure!

There are many more things on the list that north americans love, but are impossible in this crowded country.

So as a Dutch citizen who has lived in the USA and has visited Canada, I can definitely stand behind my statements regarding the differences.

Maaaan do i miss the canadian outdoors... and the lovely wide roads on which people stick to their lane instead of trying to peep in and cut off others constantly. The sense of freedom and calmness is something I cant get in Holland. Again, the grass is often greener on the other side ;). Apologies for my english.

author: CarnivoreBunny
text:
In the US we would never tolerate this system. Few Americans would favor the tax increases the municipal governments would need to implement such a system. Also, there would need to be statewide level coordination because a uniform disposal system would be needed for all towns across a state. No state municipalities are willing to share that kind of power, so poorer communities would vote NO on any such spending proposal.

"How dare other people make us spend money we don't have", would be the complaint. Then to make it fair, rich municipalities would need to be taxed more to shoulder the cost which they will complain about as well.

In short, Americans do not tolerate being forced to make personal sacrifices for the greater good. People don't even believe in a universal greater good anymore.

We're individualists who carry our trash to the curb "like real men" and deal with our garbage critters by shooting them.

author: Joan Evans
text: Years ago here in Sydney there was a proposal to build an underground vacuum tube garbage disposal system in the city. Nothing ever came of it. On the street rubbish bins would be "bottomless", garbage would fall into a large vacuum tube and be sucked along for miles to some sort of recycling disposal center. Buildings would all be connected to the same system. I'm not sure if it was the cost or the engineering that killed it. Probably both. I like this system; I just wonder if it's effective in spread out suburban locations.

Mostly wrong.
People who live in high-density housing in North America have had central garbage collection for almost a hundred years. In apartment blocks, the trash is collected in a central room under the building. Surprised this guy doesn't know that. In suburban Amsterdam, trash is collected from mobile bins on a predetermined weekday.
Also, Amsterdam rhymes with hamster-damn; nobody says Awmsterdawm. Jesus.

author: Willem van den Broek
text: Me being Dutch, I live north of Amsterdam in Zaanstad, lets say 10 to 20 kilometres away from Amsterdam,  I can tell you that this movie is not entirely true, not all off Amsterdam has street containers (as they are called)  also he forgets to show and tell that next to these street containers very often it is a big mess of illegal dumping (you need key card to open the containers) , not to forget many streets in Amsterdam (and other places in the Netherlands) are filled with garbage because people don't give a F. Well for the town were I am living we have a 3 bins in our garden 1 for Paper which is being collected 1 time every 4 weeks, then we have a bin for plastic which is also collected 1 time every 4 weeks and depending of the period 2 (Winter/autumn)  to 4 times (Summer/Spring) every 4 weeks (Vegetables, Fruit and garden waste), and that is not on the same day, so every week I need to role a bin out on to the pavement so it will be emptied, Oh yes the rest of the crap goes in a container in the street like in this movie, that is only for the small stuff and some places in The Netherlands they even weigh the stuff you put in and you get a bill for it. Also when 1 of those street containers is full or malfunctioning , you can most of the time bring it to another street container, but like most of the lazy Dutch they just dump their bag next to the container and leave it there for someone else to get rid of it.

Some places do have racoon problems, strap a bungee cord with the hooks on the end across the top of your can and boom, racoon proof. youll only see racoons in rural areas fyi. stop acting like you dont have trash day, because you have trash day every time you have to walk your ass to your garbage can around the corner. amsterdams rivers are DISGUSTING but some how they care about how they manage their trash lol

text: Just visited Amsterdam a few weeks ago. Huge metropolitan area where "best practices" for many parts of life are everyday living. However, what happens to that compacted trash?  Where we live we're supposed to separate recyclables but we still have "ginormous" landfills. Think I'll do some research. I believe we can learn from one another if we bypass the "bureaucracies" and in the US that's challenging as we have towns/cities, metropolitan areas (counties), states, federal, etc. Let's be more forward focused while coping with the everyday challenges.

author: Supadubya
text:
Before I see one more idiotic comment about graphite pencils in space- they didn't use them. Other, wax-based pencils aree used instead:

Grease ("Oil") Pencil
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grease_pencil
Wax/Colored Pencil
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colored_pencil

Both are based on wax-like substances that are non-conductive, and in the case of types used in space, don't form hard chips. Space pens, despite the money invested in them (by a PRIVATE entrepreneur with government connections looking to get rich quick) see relatively little use. Pilots in particular were already accustomed to using Grease Pencils in their military careers before joining the first space agencies.

author: Aloysius Snailchaser
text:
We have a similar system here in Catalunya. It works very well, except for the selfish minority for whom it’s too much trouble to actually put the rubbish in the bins.

We don’t have musical dustcarts but we have a knife grinder who comes a couple of times a year and plays a scale on the pan pipes to let us know he’s here. His bicycle is also his grinding machine. He puts it on a stand, and the rear wheel has a second rim without a tire. He puts a belt on it that drives his grinding wheel and pedals the knives sharp.

We also have musical schools. To call the students to class music is played over the PA outside. Everything from Motörhead to Ella Fitzgerald and the Dubliners.

author: Abdul Masaiev
text:
The story of the space pen is worse than untrue, as not only is it that but using a pencil is legitimately the stupid thing to do. Pencils work by scribbling with graphene, which is the writing core inside the wooden outer shell. Use a pencil and bits of graphene will chip off, which isn't really a big deal... if you have gravity that will generally keep them down (rather than have them flying all over the place, possibly getting anywhere at all, since they're so tiny). And aren't in a small enclosed space with only some wonky super sensitive electronics which need to work well for the mission to succeed, its failure landing on the scale from "the data's useless" to "you died". And fun fact? Graphene is highly electrically conductive. You'll probably be fine (depends on how the particles end up randomly floating), but no guarantees.

And yet, to a person who hasn't thought this through the story is super attractive, which is why it's been made up in the first place. There's an interesting lesson in it somewhere, but it's really about why that is rather than directly the "overthinking nerds lol" message of the story itself.

I was in downtown Amsterdam one summer Monday morning in 2015 while I had an 8-hour layover. Obviously the first thing I noticed was the mob of bicycles. I don’t know if this was because of Sunday night parties and or that everyone just drops off their garbage on Monday mornings, but there was a massive overload and these bins must have been overloaded. There was also garbage floating in the river. It smelled like piss because they have outdoor urinals or something. Basically a spiral barricade where men can walk into and piss into a drain in the stone floor. Disgusting.

Anyways my impression of the city was that it was filthy, stunk of piss and there were prostitutes everywhere on a Monday morning at 10:00 am.

author: Bertuccio
text:
I've lived pretty much all my life in Madrid and we don't have garbage day. We have a one non-garbage day, which is saturday, but all other 6 days a week we have garbage service.

In the inner-city each building has it's own small garbage container that you get out every day around 20h and put it back in around 8h.
In the new neighbourhoods you have dedicated areas on the street where the municipality has large garbage containers sometimes underground (depending on how new the neighbourhood is) where you put your trash and it's more efficient for the city to organize the clear of those containers and for people who can take the trash out whenever they please.

we also have an app where you can tell the city when a container is full (we don't have the automated ones yet), and it works very efficiently.
you can also report on that app any kind of issue like defects on the street, and it's well attended

author: Doug Browning
text: We had a similar system downtown in Winnipeg for years. Only the bins were on the surface and served 5-10 houses each, emptied on a regular basis. They were taken away in 2014, when the city went to a unified system of wheeled garbage and recycling carts that you have to put out weekly on garbage day. Yard waste is also collected every other garbage day during spring, summer, and fall, but you have to provide the bags. Apartments and townhouse complexes have their own, private systems. We also have 3 central depots where you can drop off your waste. And before covid, there were two giveaway weekends per year where you could put reusable unwanted items out to the curb for anyone who wanted to take.

author: SmithWN Animations
text:
In my city we have those underground garbage containers and they ain't perfect:
1. Trucks which empty them are really noisy (and for some reason they empty them late in the day).
2. it takes ages to empty containers which blocks traffic in narrow streets
3. if traffic is blocked it gets even nosier because of the other cars and the constant honking
4. Recently it seems like some trucks broke and they didn't empty containers for days it was very smelly because they really need specialized trucks to empty the containers.
5. When we get sudden torrential rainfalls the containers get flooded and trash ends up all over the street. (this is rare but still super unhygienic)
6. This point depends on container type but some lids are super loud when they are closed because they use system where they are opened by stepping on metal bar which opens the lid and when you release the bar, the lid it just smashes down. (Well in theory they have mechanism which is supposed to slow down the last part of the closing but they always break)

I might be forgetting even more problems with the containers, and while the ones in the videos seem bit better when it comes to some of the points, it still doesn't solve issue with need for specialized trucks which are slow and noisy.

author: Greg Hartwick
text: Every day is garbage day in Amsterdam!! You don’t carry a fortnight’s worth of garbage to the curb. You carry your garbage to these receptacles EVERY DAY (and several times a day)!! Congratulations, you have a new hobby - taking out the garbage - seven days a week, 365 days a year!

author: Bree Badger
text:
My partner's on home dialysis - which generates a ton of trash. We missed garbage day last week. I finally took all the trash out to the bin from where we keep it in the kitchen this past weekend (cuz he's disabled and my hips don't like the stairs). The trash bin is now completely full and we've still got more trash to take out, plus we share the bin with our neighbor (we live in a duplex). I need to take all the cardboard out to the curb too, but at least that was always going to go next to the bin. At least our trash is picked up once a week here.

For those wondering about recycling, all of it is collected by the trash ppl at the same time and then the county hires ppl to sort the trash into recycling, what can be burned, and what has to go to a landfill. Frankly, I prefer it to having to sort out recycling myself. Plus, I've never lived anywhere that the landlord pays for recycling collection anyway (in a different county where that would actually matter), so I would have to take my recycling to the recycling center myself - which wasn't along any bus lines so I had to drive to get there.

author: musikSkool
text: Yes, tell us again how a rich, intelligent country can solve all its problems.  We'll just get right on that, sitting here on our pile of filth with no available jobs within 20 miles of housing we can afford.  Our criminals make more money than our police so crime is rampant.  Our economy looks like a glass half full, of acid, when any water does fall in it is instantly evaporated away.  This channel should be named "Smart people with money."  There are plenty of smart people without money, but being smart doesn't make you any money unless you live in a rich country where it is possible to turn intelligence into money.  Just look at Elon Musk, could he have started a multi billion dollar company where he grew up?  No.  Oh, but I bet you think education will save us all.  Once again, only if it is possible to turn that education into a job.  Most people that go to college don't get a job for anything they got a degree in.  Pat yourself on the back for finding a rich place to live, but don't do it with a megaphone.

author: E3gaming
text:
Ok as a Dutch guy, I can tell you it's kind of a Myth here in this video that most of the Netherlands has these fancy trash containers.
because it is true if you live in an apartment or any toll building then you are most likely to have something like this. But in a lot of Dutch regular homes we just have garbage day like everybody else.
In fact we have even giant containers like you've just showed in your video this is pretty much identical.
I do not live in a suburb I live in a pretty decent City called nieuwegein that is pretty close to the major city of Utrecht.
the fast majority of the homes near me have just normal garbage containers.

However a lot of trash containers usually get put into a central location for picking up in the neighbourhood.
Animal wise we don't have to deal with trash pandas at worst we might have to deal with a curious household cat so we don't have that problem.
Which is something I think is quite difficult to solve in Canada.
I think when you have a big household and just have to dispose of a lot of trash. there is no way to go around a trash container.
I would say a simple solution to the trash panda problem is to have a simple and basic lock that uses a universal key.

that can be opened by anyone because that animal maybe smart but I doubt it be able to
beat a simple lock.

author: Nahiag
text:
Isn't this normal? Here in my municipality in Sweden a homeowner may choose how often the garbage should be collected, and the truck will grab your bin as it's usually set close to the road.

I myself live in an apartment and we've got a system that's very close to the one in this video. The burnable trash is in one "bin", and the "compostable" (bio-fuel) is in another bin. Within the complex there is also a sorting system where one can recycle, glass, plastic, cardboard, metal, batteries. So I don't even need to leave my building to drop off most recycleables and the garbage bins are about 20-30m away from the building.

I wouldn't mind talking about it if you'd wish to know more. It's not my area of expertise but I am deputy Mayor.

author: iamsas777
text:
I live in Utrecht, the Netherlands. I think in most of Utrecht, there's still garbage day, but only for green garbage. 'Big' garbage bins are for house owners, I think that the flat people only have a really small one, but I don't see those on the street that much. The rest goes in those underground bins. There are more garbage bins for the remainder garbage, but the others aren't too far away either. I seperate the garbage for the underground bins inside and every now and then I use my bike to take it away.
There are loads of people here that put stuff next to the underground bins that doesn't even fit in the bins. That is not allowed but if there's no proof of from whom it's from, what can they really do? For stuff like old furniture (not electronics), you can make an appointment with the goverment so that they can come pick it up. There are also some places where you can bring things that you can't fit in those containers (off course not everyone has a car or can get help).
Despite there being a lot of underground bins, there's also a lot of garbage just laying around in the street. I've seen one guy just empty out his car at the street and then drive off. The bins in my area can be opened without a pass. Years back, you needed to open it with a pass. But still some people seem to be too lazy to take it to an underground place down the street.

author: Nicholas Byram
text: This system only makes sense with government subsidized incineration. In areas where landfill is the disposal method, incineration and continuous pickup is not cost-efficient or energy efficient. Amsterdam pays people to burn trash 24 hours a day which produces more CO2 than burning gas or coal for power. The electricity produced from incernerating waste just makes it "slightly less bad."

author: Stephan Bosch
text:
It might look great but it's actually bad in practice.
Lived in several places where they implemented these kind of 'solutions' from apartments to suburbs. It's always a shite show after a few weeks. The garbage piles up, you have to walk with garbage, last place I lived more than 100 meters to a flat with social housing and lots of bad elements. The surrounding neighborhood and parks instantly transformed into dumps. Oh, and the lids/sliding metal where you put the bags in are SUPER noisy, you can hear them >100 meters down the street from inside your house.

author: Megalobst,UMU
text:
Since this an old video of NJB let me point out that these containers are :
1. Its in 1min walking distance or 1 to streets away (streets are smaller in the netherlands and more dense)
2. He points out in a newer video referencing this one, the containers are always available, which means instead of waiting for the trash bin to be collected you just walk like 10/20 steps further to throw your trash into the container(if you unlucky and the container is not next to your house)
3. Because of (2.) your trash wont sit around there so less chance of animals in your trash (never experienced that myself).
4. Trash is collected in one container that serves like 10-100+ households (depending on types of households, apartments to standalone homes) making the collection of waste much easier, faster and efficient. (And since these programs are funded by taxes, not wasted taxes)

author: m ca
text: I like your channel but this is an gross simplification on how rubbish is dealt with in the Netherlands. There are 4 rubbish categories and in some regions if you live in a house you will get either 3 or 4 bins. Sometimes there could be 3 bins and then an underground collection container like the ones you show for the 4th category. If the residential area has apartment buildings then it's just underground containers and each resident gets a wireless key. Now there are more than 4 categories of rubbish so if you need to throw away Styrofoam or metal or any other material, you have in each area a Rubbish Division Station in a drive in style where you will have at least 15 to 25 rubbish categories.

In Indore, India, there is daily waste collection service. They collect it in 6 categories (on site segragation) then they recycle it. Waste that is non recyclable is burnt & that produces electricity. Degradable waste produces Compost and Bio methane (city bus runs on it).

author: Silver
text:
Those have become common in urban parts of Norway too, as overground trash containers are big, ugly and smelly.
Even cooler is a suction system, that looks similar overground. Underground the trash from multiple places gets sucked into one larger underground container. A special garbage truck comes when that container is full and sucks it all up. This saves having to go to every individual trash dropoff spot, allowing them to be built in places where one don't want traffic, like between apartment buildings. It also limits smell.

In non-urban areas the bin is still most common. As we don't have trash pandas it is not as much of a problem, and a simple strap, big rock or a shed will keep the birds of. Not all trash collectors allows sheds on garbage day, but asking never hurts.

text: In towns and cities in Australia we have similar to what you showed being carried down the stairs. Known locally as "wheelie bins", for obvious reasons. We commonly also have large plastic boxes or, sometimes, additional wheelie bins, for recycling. My family and I live in rural Australia and there is no rubbish collection. Instead, we have to take our rubbish to a collection point, about twelve kilometres from our property, where there are several large skips, which are emptied twice a week. Thankfully, we don't have trash pandas. Just poisonous snakes and spiders.

author: Kane
text:
Amsterdam's system picks up slowly, and therefore not too efficiently - they need circular/cylindrical containers, firstly. North American systems are designed to handle way more volume.
What would've been nice, is slow-combusting trash incinerator; finally leading to a pick-up by a truck. it would probably be gas, and then electric fired.
the Smoke particles would have to be dry-filtered, using centrifugal/electric forces and finally a rough filter.
Doing it this way, makes for much tidier environment. Recycling would have to be separate - if it can be monetized, even better.
In terms of Green-ecology, the governments should off-set with tree planting, and pneumatic wind-turbines, to 'fuel' a hydrogen-electric economy; high-speed rail, smaller vehicles (large fuel tanks)...etc.

author: globelthreatx
text: My only concern with this system potentially operating anywhere in the U.S., is our staggering inability to self govern and assume accountability. I.E. people can't even return a shopping cart in a parking lot because its "inconvenient". Some Complexes/Apartment/shared living spaces offer trash services where you can place your trash-bag in front of your front door between certain hours and an employee of the property management will come around and gather your trash, yet people continue to place their trash all over the complex, or at their door outside of the defined hours. That's literally as simple as it can possible get, so in comparison to walking your bag all the way down to a public sidewalk is far beyond what the average American is willing to invest effort in doing. We're just not an obedient culture and its embarrassing at times.

author: Dan Wilcox
text: At my apartment in Tulsa, Oklahoma I have to walk about one third of a city block to drop my trash in the dumpster.  Every time I am there I make sure to lift up the lid and leave it open otherwise the residents here have about a 50% chance of leaving their garbage on the ground outside the dumpster.  If Americans had to carry their garbage three or four city blocks that 50% of humanity here who will not lift the heavy dumpster lid would be dumping it on peoples lawns, in front of businesses, in the street...  I would appreciate a system where identity thieves were not digging through each trash dumpster about 500 to 1,000 times per year.  It is literally that bad here.  The trash pickup system for residential houses does have the advantage of incentivizing people to reduce their trash output so they can get by with the smaller cheaper trash bins.

In Taiwan, they don't even allow public trash cans in most places, and in Japan, forget about it! America has so many people shit where they sleep it's becoming so disgusting moving out becomes the only option.

author: colin hart
text:
As a torontonian, I'm blown away by this simple, more efficient and smarter way of doing trash collection.

Racoons are assholes, but this doesn't just make sense to block them out from the trash, but its probably MUCH cheaper for the city to collect and deal with. In Toronto, a truck needs to stop at every house during garbage day. Literally hundred and hundred of stops per block. It takes all day for garbage to be collected from 1 area.

This makes so much more sense. You basically pool a while blocks worth of garbage in one location giving the trucks WAY less stops to make.

Jesus. This is the way it should be done. Can't believe I've never thought of a concept like this, it's just... Superior.

text: " We have no garbage day in AhMsterdam" yes you do but because you do not have to deal with it you think there is none. You wish to know why recycling and garbage fails in America and Canada? Because we pay for it and the companies who provide the service are in it to make a profit and provide stocks. meanwhile in AHMsterdam you pay more taxes which provide for that service. A prime example of recyclables in California is you get this tiny fucking tub that barely holds 30 crushed aluminum cans and are expected to put ALL your recyclables into it the not to mention you are paying for this "service" with no kick back on the value of the recycled material. Putting giant "kiosks" fixed this somewhat then the cities that put out the kiosks got tired of homeless people breaking into their kiosks so they removed them...hmm who'd think that the cities were making money off something people were giving them for free and then bitching about people who had no money "stealing" their free money. The problem comes down to American and Canadian cities being run by idiots who do not understand how to run a city properly and think of  garbage and a hinderance and not a service...unless it makes them free money to which they will go to any lengths to keep.

author: Lora Coggins
text: In some American college campuses, there are recycling compactors like the ones in this video. However, in my experience, they are still riddled by unwanted visitors - not crows or raccoons, but by wasps! It gets crazy in the spring and fall. I find the indoor trash rooms in dorms and apartment buildings to be very useful for the people living in these buildings (you don't even have to worry about going outside!). But having also grown up in a household, I do also dread having to take out the trash every Tuesday.

author: smileyeagle1021
text: Honestly, the main thing I miss from living in an apartment was the ability to just take my trash to the dumpster any time.  Some weeks I completely overflow my bin and some weeks I have barely anything in it at all, I have to pay extra if I overfill my bin too much but get no discount for being nearly empty. Every Monday morning (our garbage day) I have to do the mental math on whether or not to take out the not full trash bag in the kitchen because this week the bin has a lot of extra space, but next week it might not. author: Gaming Scientist
text: One thing to keep in mind about that ball point pen for NASA story; graphite from pencils can cause short circuits in space craft. Micro gravity causes graphite particles to float everywhere, and it can get into the critical circuitry that keeps astronauts alive. It can get worse than just short circuits; graphite particles could cause a fire in the space craft by creating sparks in the circuitry. So yes, the money spent on developing a pen that can write in zero gravity was money well spent.

"We have no garbage day in Amsterdam!" Really now? Well I guess when everyday is your birthday, you have no birthday.
Problems with animals and smell? The simplest and cheapest solution is a small shed around the bins with a simple lock(mine was ~$200 for a place that has around 8 bins). Now this is the pen to your space problem. It's way more inconvenient to take out the trash down the street every few days. And I'm sure there are some hidden problems that you find out only when you've regularly used them for a decent period of time, that you've "forgot" to point out.

author: Kutsy
text:
Kinda reminds me of some other european counties where instead of having any complex underground storage facilities, they just have large bins that sit by the local road outside the apartaments. The bins are large to accomodate for the whole buildings trash, you just grab your trashbag and walk it outside to the bin. The lids are heavy enough that no city animal will be able to open it but a child would. Its designed to be easily picked up by the garbage truck and since it sits by the road, it literaly takes them less than 5 minutes to empty all of them.
Honestly, I feel like having them underground just overcomplicates things for no reason. It would be harder to replace them, harder to maintain them, and you need specialized trucks to pick the trash up.

As a resident of the city of Amsterdam i can tell you: this system stinks.
The municipality uses it as a way to cut costs on collecting garbage and will leave a container full/overflowing for days and days.
Their stance is: if it's full you wait or walk a long way hauling a heavey bag of trash.

in theory this system is great, but in practice, the municipality abuses the fact that you see the garbage to collect as little as they can get away with....

author: Ryan Roberts
text:
We don't have garbage day in North Carolina either. There are two piles - stuff that burns ("recycling") and stuff that stinks. The paper/cardboard gets torched about every 2 weeks, and the ash goes in the compost pile. The actual garbage goes just down the street to the "dump", which is more of a transfer station with a giant dumpster/compactor. Free to use, open 7 days a week. Don't have to go to the dump very often, food waste normally gets thrown out into the yard through the window where it is always gone by morning.

The fancy people can still pay to have a can picked up, but it's not very common. I think the garbage company only has one truck.

I can't understand why people cram themselves into cities...

author: Max
text:
it's a thing that i see slowly being deployed across western europe, usually in new-built city blocks for cities.

garbage days are still the norm for much of the region because in most cities, useful space is already occupied so installing underground garbo containers in a dense enough pattern as to make standard containers superflous will involve removing stuff, be it parking and road space, green zones or even entire buildings in extreme cases; in addition that the bins have to be near a road that the truck can access and that the whole system has to be at a price the city is willing and has the budget to pay for, a lot of these are not given

author: Henry Potter

author: Pook
text: Where I live you have to have 2 containers, one for recycling and one for garbage.  We had to buy a second garbage cart because of our volume, at $75 and wait a month to get it.  And woe betide if your lid is open even one inch; they refuse to take your garbage, leaving it to sit in the Florida sun and marinate another week.  After one hurricane a freezer's worth of food sat in the cart for 2 weeks and the stink was monumental.  And, you have to know which week is yard trash and which is household bulk trash, and if you get it wrong there it sits.  Unless of course you haul it back off the curb and store it.  Our so-called recycling is a joke.  They won't take glass, they don't want boxes broken down, and what they do take is baled and left sitting in a former landfill.  Before Waste Connections took over and we had to pay $175/yr for piss-poor service, we had twice a week pickup and MUCH better service.  But this is our county commission's idea of "progress".  Progress SUCKS!

author: A YouTuber
text:
This works fine in dense cities since houses are close enough together.
The reason for the bins is because of the distance between homes, lots of people do not want to walk far down the street to take out their trash.

Currently I'm living in both a house and an apartment building in Vienna depending on the weekday, Apartment building I don't need to care what day it is as there are large bins in "trash rooms" for everything except bio, glass and plastic, with those bins being at every second street corner or so.

For house, the next house is around 50m away, going all the way down the hill, that's not even close to dense enough for such a system to make sense/worth the investment.

author: Luc René de Cotret
text:
While I agree that this system offers an elegant solution to keep the streets free of the clutter of bins and bags full of smelly waste, there’s one thing you haven’t mentionned in your video: how is this paid for?

Everywhere I’ve lived, the cities imposed taxes for garbage collection. I’ve seen different systems to finance this operation. Some cities impose quotas, where you pay a fixed amount per year and you’re either allowed a certain volume of bags per pickup (or one bin per household), or a limited number of pickups per year, or limited to a certain total weight of waste collected (bins have microchips and your waste is weighed on pickup). Anything exceeding the defined quota will result in a surcharge at the end of the year.

Other cities have you pay proportionally for what you put out by having you put your waste in official bags which cost a ton (this is how the taxes are collected in this scenario). The more you sort, reuse and recycle, the less you’ll need to pay. Throwing away household garbage in public bins is prohibited as those are not subject to any of these forms of control. You can be severely fined for bringing a bag out of your home and throwing it on the public bins intended for pedestrians to throw their chocolate wrappers and such.

In a system where garbage bins are in public space and shared by everyone, how can you pinpoint and make responsible people who fail to sort their trash, or throw away excessive amounts of waste? What’s in place to reward people for reducing their household waste by recycling more or composting? There don’t seem to be any forms of control on any of that. I can only image a per-capita or per-household fixed tax to handle the overall costs of the operation divided evenly. I’m not convinced this system will help reduce overall waste or improve sorting or adopting ecological behaviour. It just takes the garbage out of sight, and no one can actually tell how good or bad the situation is, and no one needs to take responsibility for being trash at sorting trash.

My city in Maharashtra, India has garbage vehicles that play a song about garbage on full volume on repeat. I always wonder how the driver manages to stay sane.
