"Look, don't throw here and there,
Diseases will spread, everyone will suffer,
So what should we do?
Garbage man is here, bring your garbage out of your homes.. (x4)"
(Followed by a rap on garbage)

I had fun that one time when i was in meeting WFH, and had to explain my manager what's going on.

Edit: the song is 'gaadiwala aya gharse kachra nikal' if anyone's curious.

In my county in Ontario, the garbage truck drives weekly to everyones rural street and collects garbage on the side of the road, which has to be tagged witha $4.25 tag, and god help if litter gets blown into the ditch or woodland before its picked up. We just don't live close enough together for this to be practical. Plus, because our blocks are bigger, we have lots of green rubbish (branches, leaves) which get composted along with your food. We have three bins: small red (for just rubbish: dirty nappies, unrecyclable plastics, stuff that can't be recycled nor composted), large yellow (for recycling; can't add soft plastics now though, need to go to your supermarket) and large green (composting food and plant materials). We don't have a need either, no animals get into the bins.

author: Roadrunner
text:
Heyo! Dutch sanitation worker here! I actually empty these for a living (though not in Amsterdam) here's a couple fun facts for those of you who are interested;

- The containers for glass, packaging, paper, and textiles are usually grouped together in so-called 'recycling islands' or 'recycling streets'. These containers are emptied on a shedule like mentioned in the video. Ideally, the truck comes by when the container is just about full.

-The 'waste' containers (for non-recyclables) operate on a pay-per-click system, using a contactless household-bound smart card. The card opens the drum once, after which you can put a 60 or 30L bag in, and close it, which rotates the drum so the bag falls into the container.

-The container registers this action as one 'click' and it knows how many clicks it can take before it's full. Once it's at about 60%, it sends a signal to HQ and gets put on the route for the next day.

-When the truck comes by to empty the waste containers, after putting it back into the ground, the worker will swipe a special badge over the container display, resetting the 'click counter'.

-Using this system, the trucks only head out to 60-100% full containers, maximizing efficiency, and in our case, one truck is enough to cover 90.000 inhabitants on a 5-day 8-hour shedule.

-Containers can have many different mechanisms for lifting and discharging via truck-mounted crane! In the video, you see the so-called "mushroom" system, allowing the operator to empty the container and put it back into the pit, all without having to do ANY manual labor.

-Waste containers only need a small solar cell to power the locking mechanism and the click counter!

-Compactor containers like the one in the video are powered by a power supply that's mounted inside the pit. These containers have a screw compactor inside, and a laser tripwire that activates it when an x amount of bags have been dropped into the container!

-Depending on the company, area, and circumstances, crane trucks can empty between 50 and 120 containers per day! Trucks are typically operated by one person, who drives the truck to the various locations, gets out, and empties the containers via remote-control truck-mounted crane.

-Our trucks (like most in the business) have crane-mounted weighing systems, that can weigh a container in the air, once when full, and once when empty. This way, using geodata, the system knows which container we're loading based on our current location, and keeps track of the volume of each container when emptied. This data is then used to optimize routes, and move the emptying times backward or forward on the shedule as needed.

author: ThePizzaMuncher
text:
The area I live in in Harlingen, Friesland (I guess it's kind of the smaller town version of a suburb, it's almost purely residential with in our case 2 churches, a supermarket with a bakery next to it and a local owned snackshack (no really, it's a shack); most of the houses are the classic 2 story row houses) still has garbage day, but we have 2 of those iconic somewhat tall 2 wheeled garbage bins, one for GFT (biowaste with some caveats) and one for everything short of massive, dangerous, electrical or chemical waste. Alternating fortnightly pickups for each. Sometimes we do have too much, but honestly it would be impressive to constantly run up against the size limit when the bin is literally above waist height for a grown man. We also don't really have the panda problem here, so that's probably why communal underground dumps are a more recent and more urban development here.

Honestly, I think I'd enjoy using a communal dump, but I don't know how people that have any sort of lawn would deal with that. Maybe they'd tile the entire thing. That'd be useful for bbq's in cat-heavy neighbourboods too, sometimes freeroam cats are a lawn nightmare.

author: Camille
text: In France, we have both communal bins such as these, as well as ones in our buildings. I'm not sure what people do when they have houses, because not many people do in cities, and then in smaller towns or villages, I don't know what the schedule for bin pick-up is. But in cities, apartment buildings will have a certain amount of general waste and recycling bins, which the company who is in charge of cleaning the building will take out when needed. The bins are usually in a closed space, next to the garage if there's one, and if there isn't, they'll be in a designated space everyone in the building can access, and which is usually sheltered in some way. I have no idea what the schedule is in my city, but I know the bins are usually picked up quite late at night or early in the morning, to avoid being in everyone else's way, unlike in Australia, where they come around during the day, which also means the bins stay outside all day long, often all night long too, cause people take them out the night before, as per councils' recommendations. I love watching the big communal bins being emptied, I find it facisnating to see the massive metal box coming out of the ground (the ones where I'm from are a lot bigger than the ones you've shown, which is why it's fascinating to me). And when they empty the glass one, oh boy do you know it! It's very loud. Which is probably why they do it during the day for this one, cause it'd wake up everyone in the neighbourhood otherwise!

author: Patrick Wingert
text: Garbage trucks are less fuel-efficient than an M1 Abrahams tank so the fewer stops it must make the less it costs to run. stopping and starting outside of every couple of houses across the city means it gets gallons per mile instead of miles per gallon! Apartment buildings are the worst. people put 55" tv's into the organic recycling bin which means it is now contaminated and becomes ordinary garbage. Nothing is separated and 80% of the tenants just drop their garbage down the garbage shoot so recycling is only about 1`0% and 90% ends up in landfills. I love low-income people in Toronto social housing. If it doesn't involve getting drunk, fighting about money for crack, or trading girls like hockey cards to earn money from prostitution they don't care! Proper garbage and recycling separation is not even a slight consideration for them. It's the cities problem, let them go through the garbage and separate it out.

author: TheEsyz
text:
As a former Amsterdam garbage man, this is not entirely true.
I literally worked with the men I recognized in this video and in still the majority of Amsterdam people still have bins and garbage day. In the centre we don't have the space for underground bins because of the age of the city so they are allowed to throw trash bags on the sidewalk and we'll pick them up in trucks. And in outter suburbs like Nieuw West and Noord, they still use bins and we collect those normally with a route each day. There are also mixtures of both. For example north only had 1 or 2 bin crews. (That picked up bins) as most areas used underground containers like this. But areas like Nieuw West still used 4 to 6 bin trucks.

author: floobertuber
text:
I have those traditional-looking wheeled trash bins for my garbage and recycling service. To keep the animals out, I just keep a dog leash hooked over the lid, except at pickup time.

So far, no critters have ever gotten in. Granted, this doesn't cover the several hours that the bins are roadside for pickup (as I have to remove the strap so the truck can robo-grab the bin and dump it), but that exposure is a tiny fraction of daylight hours and hasn't been an issue.

EDIT: I might actually prefer having the sort of centralized pickup documented in the video, but I live in a rural area. Such a sidewalk underground service may be fantastic in urban areas, but would be severely impractical because in places like where I live.

I miss garbage day very often and you need more bins, more people with heavy work and it also saves space in your own house. Here you need at least 2-3m² from your house just for the trash bins. So you pay the trash bins, the square meter, the box they are in and we pay more cause the work takes more time and is harder.

author: 2484marshall
text: I remember seeing something about these a few years ago and thought 'why is that not everywhere?!' It's particularly an issue in some city areas with terraced, on-street housing. Wheelie bins are not allowed to be left on the street, and (certainly in the UK) the back alleyway is usually filled with rubbish anyway so you can't 'wheel' one round from your back yard. As such people keep it in bags still which end up piled up kerb side pending 'garbage day'. This creates problems and often just leads people to be lazier and dumping their rubbish either in the street or the rear alleyway. This option would definately make more sense in those situations. Reminds me a bit of a campsite system.

Never mind those trash Pandas. Think about restaurant alleys and it’s assortment of rats crawling through those back alley dumpsters.

Very common in Boston and New York four story Prewar multi tenant brick buildings.

Slumlords with entire buildings under management would place the trash collection dumpster at the back alley filled to the brim. 

The savvy and more conscious ones would assign a corner in the basement, all bins lids tightly shut.

author: Henrik Myrhaug
text:
In the neighborhood I grew up in in Norway, houses and gardens are designed such that we have bins that are placed next to the road, that way the garbage trucks just come by and the workers roll the bins 2 meters over to the truck and back, so garbage day was never a problem. When we moved to Germany (more specifically the suburbs of Cologne), we had the bins inside a fence on our property, so we had to remember to roll the bins out onto the sidewalk, wich was kinda annoying, but no big deal.
Where I live now, I have to walk 70 meters from my apartment to throw trash in an underground container, wich is much more annoying than simply walking 5 meters outside the door, or even remembering trash day once every two weeks.

We don't have any animal problems, so underground containers are just an annoyance for me.

author: Mark's Adventures

I put a clamp on that screwed the bin shut and locked I only took it off to put waste in or for collection and only put the bins out the morning of collection 07:00 am they showed at 09:00 am.

author: No Name
text: Not a bad system, but honestly, I think I'd find it fairly annoying to have to walk down the block every time I have to take a bag of garbage out of my house (especially if it's late on a winter night with frigid winds or there's a bad rainstorm).  I'd rather have the big bin within a few feet of my back door and then cart the big bin out to the curb once a week.  As far as racoons, mine were easily thwarted by sticking a nail through a tiny hole I made that runs through both the front of the lid and the lip of the trashcan.  Can't open the lid without removing the nail, and the racoons have proven to be either too dense or too weak to pull it out.

author: stevieinselby
text: I guess this is the kind of thing that can work well in densely-packed city centres, but in lower density areas it is hard to see it being effective as it would either need a high number of underground bins per head or people would have to carry their rubbish a lot further. And if you have to carry rubbish further, and carry all the different types of recycling separately, I can imagine a lot more people wouldn't bother to separate it out – especially if you have to feed the recycling in a bit at a time – and would just junk everything into general waste.

author: Lisette Z
text: I am Dutch. I live in a rural village and we have 3 garbage containers behind the house and trash days to worry about. I actually hated the underground containers when we lived in the cities. You pay per time you use the underground container so you only trash completely full trashbags. In the summer in a south facing appartment it would get so gross with all food scraps and fruit flies. We'd have to worry about maggots and everything in the house. Now, we take our food scraps outside every day and it's so much cleaner! Also, it's much cheaper because we only pay for 1 container. The compost bin and recycling bin are free to empty.

author: chilanya
text: I'm Dutch and the underground system is only is city centers. smaller towns still use the bins or use a combination. Personally i have a bin for paper & cardboard, and another one for compostables (gft, natural stuff like fruit peels, egg shells, weeds from your garden etc), but the plastic goes into an underground thing, and so does the "restafval" (whatever doesn't fit in the previous categories.) . Then there's also above-ground containers for recycling glass, textiles, and cans. empty batteries go into a recycling bin in the supermarket.

author: GingerKiwi
text:
Totally awesome!
Found your channel about a month ago, and am really enjoying it.
I’ve been living in mid-town Toronto for almost 6 years - near “Yonge and Eligible” (Yonge Street and Eglinton Ave) and the constant construction. Raccoons are in my building’s recycling and green (compost) bins every night (and there’s not enough bins for the complex of 3 small walk up apartment buildings, so recycling is often in random bags by the doors to the backyard.
A high school friend from Scarborough (eastern Toronto) once saw a parent raccoon teach a baby how to open a garage door then open the bins inside.
Trash pandas/raccoons are why the cool (small) Canadian mug/socks/gifts company chose this mug as it’s novelty mug for Toronto: https://mainandlocal.com/collections/novelty-mugs/products/raccoon-mug (FYI I’m just a happy customer. Great mugs!)
Anyways hope not too long a comment. Love your channel (including the grocery shopping GoPro vid ;-) ).

author: Educational YouTube
text:
In the US at least, if you live in the city center or an apartment, you just have a big dumpster and the city handles picking it up. Underground or dumpster systems don't work well for diffuse, suburban neighborhoods.

There is one HUGE advantage to the system you're under as compared to the US though -- underground trash has a smaller footprint, so you can actually have trash cans dispersed throughout the city that aren't just constantly overflowing with garbage. Dumpsters are also pretty difficult to put trash into if they're closed, which they often are, so this feels like a big win.

author: Kynsia
text:
Downsides of these bins is that they reaaaally attract fly-tippers. I lived in a student apartment complex (which was messy enough because of the frequency of moving) and nearby companies or people from the other blocks who had forgotten about trash day (because they still had bins) would dump their garbage with us. It wasn't the fancy ones with a sensor, so they were full ALL THE TIME. The city for some reason refused to come pick it up more often because they had some fancy algorithm that said it couldn't be that bad
(I'm still not saying that normal bins would have been better though... Can't imagine how many we would have needed for the 700+ students living there...)

author: Ana Luísa
text:
In my city in Brazil we have 4 garbage days per week. One is for recyclables, and the other three for common trash (as my street has a street fair every saturday, in this day they come twice, one for cleaning the street and picking up trash from the stands, and the other for the house's trash).
If you try to put recyclables in the wrong day, they won't pick it up, and vice versa, because they feel the weight and know it's the wrong day, this way the city makes people put trash in the right day.
And people really respect it! We only see the trash bags a few hours before they collect it, and if they don't collect we put it back inside and try another day.
Also, if it is way too heavy (usually when you are building your house or modificating it), you need to call a special number to pick it up, or hire a business that specializes in this type of trash.

This way my city is one of the cleanest I've ever been, and I love it!

author: Robert Kribs
text:
I must say that there are huge differences in approach to garbage collection throughout NY state - even between communities only a few miles apart. The state is likely a microcosm of the world. My city (Syracuse NY) started an aggressive recycling program long before it was a household word but now with changes in the recycling market place (especially China no longer buying US recyclables) much more of our waste is going to local landfills. The local agency brags that 56% of our local waste is recycled so that gives me hope. In addition the non-recycled waste is burned in an emission controlled plant (heavily regulated) that produces enough electricity to power 30,000 homes. The burning reduces the amount of solid waste that goes to landfills by 90%. That's encouraging too but it's still not enough in my book.

Many of us are familiar with the garbage chutes in large apartment buildings with no responsibility for the tenant to do anything but throw a bag down a chute. In some cities in NY the landlords are responsible to get the trash to the curb for a weekly public pickup and in others a private contractor must be hired. In most of the cities in NY, residential neighborhoods the trash/recycling pick up is weekly but the degree of recycling varies quite a bit. There is no law requiring recycling. It's not a surprise that NYC recycles less than 20% of its waste.

In suburban areas outside of Syracuse there is very limited public trash pick up. A few villages provide the weekly service but most towns require you to hire a private contractor. Interestingly some municipalities in NY (including the city of Buffalo) require the use of residential garbage cans that can be picked up by a mechanical arm attached to the garbage truck. It is illegal for residents of NY to burn trash so even the rural towns have to figure it out and my guess is that the large portion of trash in NY outside of the cities is picked up by privately hired contractors.

author: simonriddick
text: Canada here. I have mostly recyclables but food scraps I put in a container and freeze in the freezer and then put in my compost when it gets full. I started doing that because the animals tear into any bag that smells like food. I even used heavy duty bags and doubled up and they still get in. If I do have a garbage bag that smells a bit I take it out in the morning before I leave for work so it's not outside all night for them to get to. The green bins are a joke no way i'm leaving that rotten thing near the house. Also you have to buy bags extra for them screw that. Also here every week is recycling and you have to wait 2 weeks for garbage and green bin. Imagine 2 weeks in the summer with food rotting away in a green bin. Another problem with blue bins is when it gets windy garbage goes flying down the street. I see it all the time it makes one hell of a mess sometimes. The derelicts up the street don't follow any rules and have clear bags or put out car tires or whatever random shit they need out. I think too putting the food in the compost is much better anyways because it feeds the squirrels and trash pandas and skunks so they aren't so aggressive for the garbage bags. One time I went out there and I had 2 cats 2 trash pandas and a skunk all hanging out back there lol. I turned my flashlight on and said hey what's going on back here and they all looked at me lol. Meow!.

author: Ms10000123
text:
These are more of a 'apartments don't have yards' solution than a 'superior system compared to bins' solution.

The bins in the Netherlands have wheels, are sturdy enough to keep pests out and can be used without a bag. On any day you can just throw your stuff in your bins and you roll them out on garbage day to pick them up later when you have the time.

Being in control of your bins is just way better. These containers are overly full at times, causing piles to form around them. The lack of responsibility is just too detrimental. There are also cases of people throwing in burning material or a roaming cat in them requiring emergency services to be involved.

And perhaps the biggest long-term issue is that sorting waste for recycling becomes way to inconvenient. I live in a place that uses these and if I want to separate plastic I'd need a separate bag to carry it 4 streets to a container. And paper isn't even in such a system, likely because of the fire hazard it would pose. And you can't really empty out into these containers either, so you basically have to make lots of little trips or use bags for every kind of trash.

There are a lot of them, so that each "bin shelter" can serve multiple houses but not too many, so they don't overfill. No one cares about the garbage day either. And if the bin is full, you can always call the right city service and they will come and collect the trash. It all depends on the city tho. Some might have problems with it, etc. my hometown had some areas where those bins quickly overfilled and the city didn't care. I don't know how the situation looks like in the small towns and villages tho.

They would not take a blind bit of notice of recycling either  - it would all go into the nearest street bin. DIY construction waste would go in there as well. I travel to Amsterdam from the UK regularly as I have family there, and I have seen it being abused there  frequently. I have to admit I have done so.  In the UK if I put non recyclable material in the wrong bag, the waste disposal company would just leave it behind.

author: theBabyDead
text:
You seem to be a big fan of this but it has tons of disadvantages as well. Besides this, it only really gets used extensively in busy cities. On any outside region and/or town, it'll mostly still be bins with garbage day.

One big disadvantage of this system is how little fits in it. Another is that more often than not, you actually pay per opening of these underground containers. And where I don't stack a lot of trash, it'd be nice if I could dump my trash ANYWHERE outside of my appartment until I actually have a lot of it to not insanely overpay. It costs me 5 euro to open the bin just once and it takes about a 60L garbage bag. It takes me about 4 months to fill a 60L garbage bag. Imagine how much money I'd waste just to take my trash out weekly just to prevent the smell...

For example I did not find a place that would take both glass and plastic. I found that very odd. I guess many will just through everything into the “other” bin instead then.

author: BlazinGTO
text:
Very interesting, never saw this before. If I lived in an apartment nearby to one of those and they were never full, great! But what happens when it's full and who wants to put in bottles one at a time? What do you do with large styrofoam and large cardboard? Cutting/breaking it?

This system only looks like it works in some situations. Mainly this looks ok for newer cities. But what about rural areas and older cities? The smaller the country and the more densely packed the population makes this work better. Also, it's not always so easy to just dig a large hole anywhere you want in a city. Many things can already be underground there. Any city that has overhead power lines will also have a problem, it looks like the truck has to lift really high into the air.

Also, I would consider the days the bins get emptied as "trash days". You still have a large truck, noise, smell, etc. Some places will have it picked up on a certain day of the week and others only when they get full, but those are the trash days.

This apartment area is like 2 blocks of 5-7 apartment building with 18 flats per building, and there are at the end of each block theese kinda domes with the same kinda round trap door as the old garbage chutes, and in there is a pit so deep, that a child that fell into 1 around here could not even be rescued by rope or anything, they had to wait for a wheelloader to come lift the whole thing up. Also not everyone loves these things. A disabled friend living in Utrecht would love to recycle, but isn't able to, because he has to make a 'trip' to the trash shutes each time a bag fills up.

author: Mehmet Doğan Özdemir
text: In Turkey garbage trucks collect the garbage daily. Every apartment has a garbage and cleaning employee, we call them "kapıcı" which translates to "door keeper". They're not full-time employees. They just come to collect the garbage in the evenings and clean the apartment once every weekend. So the "kapıcı" collects the trash of the apartment right before the garbage truck arrives, and puts them in front of the apartment. Then the garbage trucks collect the whole city's garbage every evening. We just have to put the trash in a big black plastic bag and we are only allowed to put the garbage bags in front of apartments in certain timespans, otherwise we pay some fine. I think the Amsterdam model is much better because we waste lots of plastic bags overtime.

You miss a cruicial detail in this design: unless you put them in front of every house and have them locked up, there is no way to attribute every piece of trash to a person. That's just communism. I live in Germany in a small village and people get angry, ANGRY, that there are some freeloaders who once in a while will use the public trash cans in the park to get rid of their trash from home. No. Not on the watch of the town gossip. Everyone has to pay for every bin, so if it is half full you are encouraged to wait out to the next trash day, getting the waste steamy. author: Alex Chen
text: I don’t think the Dutch underground solution would work well in a subtropical environment. The cockroaches will be having a feast. Also there would be a stench from rotting and spoiled food in the summer heat. It will be very difficult to make sure that the plastic bags used to contain food do not leak. That would also make a mess of the trash containers. So, the best solution was to have the trucks come just about every day. That way, you don’t need to keep any spoiling food around the apartment. You clean it out just about every day. You don’t need to walk far either because the trucks can easily make the necessary stops so that no one would need to walk more than half a block. The sanitation workers are there also to help sort out what are recyclables and food wastes. There used to be big huge metal bins where the trash was left for a week. Basically you ended up in a smelly neighborhood with an infestation of fearless cockroaches and giant well-fed rats. The cost increase in instituting the above approach is minimal but the returns transformed the neighborhood from a smelly one to one you can breathe freely.

author: Oedhel Setren
text:
It a great idea on the surface but the immediate pitfalls are obvious. 1) No viable way to efficiently implement this is low population areas. 2) These public bins take up public space, which is becoming increasingly rare. 3) In the US, most of our population is financially responsible for removing their garbage while also providing free recycling. This prompts people to be more conscientious of what they are throwing in the garbage bin vs the recycling bin.

With this system I see everyone just throwing out everything.

author: Severity One
text:
Where I live (Malta), in the village I live in normal rubbish is picked up on Mondays, Thursdays and Saturdays; recyclables on Tuesdays and Fridays; organic waste on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. Glass is picked up every second Thursday, and you can take out garden waste on certain days as well. If you have bulky refuse, you ring the local council, take it out on the pavement, and they come and pick it up. And then there are Civic Amenities sites, where you can drop all kinds of waste to be recycled, including white goods, computers, TVs, etc. These are open every day of the year, and there's one on the outskirts of my village.

That STILL doesn't stop people from dumping waste in the countryside, though. Sigh...

author: Cadde
text:
Where i live we used to have a garbage chute where everyone could simply open their front door and drop their garbage bags down the chute to a room at the bottom floor of the building.
Then a garbage truck came by every Thursday and emptied each room around the block.
It worked beautifully, it was clean, quick, efficient and very convenient. I could, rather than waste plastic bags for my garbage, throw milk cartons and other bigger trash items right down the chute.
The only downside was some noise on Thursdays when they were emptied (day time of course) and occasionally when people threw heavy stuff down the chutes which ended with a big bang at the bottom floor.

One particular area even had a automated collection system in place, where each garbage bag thrown down the chute were conveyed via a screw underground to a central location where it was compacted into a container.
On "garbage day", the "garbage truck" (container truck) only needed to hook the container and replace it with an empty one.
Of course, that system eventually broke down because people stupidly threw all kinds of junk down said chutes rather than just soft household garbage.
But the tunnels are still there, waiting to be repaired. It was a super efficient system.

They closed these down for some stupid reason, it was a near perfect system really.
Nowadays, you have to go down to the bottom floor, all the way out to a building located at the parking lot and throw your garbage in open bins.
That building smells of absolute ASS, it's locked with a keycard lock so you have to have that ready while also holding a bag of garbage.
People throw their garbage RIGHT ON THE FLOOR because they don't want to enter the building seeing as how filthy and smelly it is. Opening the door from the inside makes you wanna wash your hands with sulfuric acid right away.
Many times, people don't even open the door to the building but rather dump their garbage outside the door so seagulls and rats flock around said garbage until it's blown literally EVERYWHERE.
AND, many people put their garbage bags outside their apartment doors in wait for the next time they are going to go to the building... So the whole access stairwell smells of garbage and discarded diapers.
And of course it's a hazard.

I disagree with your notion that these are any good. What's good is some way of dumping your garbage down a chute conveniently and then having all that garbage end up in a central location to be picked up by a simple container truck.
Sure, it's more expensive that way but the convenience and efficiency is par none.

author: Laura Sanchez
text: I live in the Netherlands and these underground containers SUCK! First I could just put the container in my front yard and roll it to the side of the street once a week, now when I have garbage I gotta take the garbage all the way to the end of the street where they have some of these containers, not very fun when it's heavy or when it's raining or when I just wanna put something in the garbage outside in my pjs without my neighbors seeing. And also, half the time these underground containers are stuck or full so they don't open. Which means people leave their garbage next to it, which smells for the people living around it but it's also just disgusting to look at and it gives us rats. But not to worry, the government knows how to deter criminals! They search through your garbage if you leave it next to the containers for anything with an address on it. Most people don't throw away anything with their address on it, but my dumbass walked passed the container (not knowing this) with a note that I no longer needed, with my address on it. So I decided to stuff that little piece of paper in one of the garbage bags that was already standing next to the underground container, and a week later I got a ticket for putting "my garbage" next to the container. If I had just thrown the piece of paper I wouldn't have got a ticket, but I know not to litter so I put it in a garbage bag and that's what happens. Well, that's my rant about underground containers. I didn't proofread this so I hope it makes sense lol

author: Ziya Erol Kılıç
text: I Germany there are regular garbage bins and we do not have to carry them. They are usually stored in front of houses and building or sometimes in the backyard. Nobody has to bring them out front on garbage day. The garbage men have keys to get the garbage bins. I do not know for sure when our garbage gets picked up because I do not have to. If you have a problem with rats, mice or maybe foxes in your trash (we have no trash pandas here) or others are using your bins you can get garbage bins with locks. The garbage men have master keys and can open them when needed. We have special containers for glass and paper that everyone can use. Paper gets full quite fast because only some people have paper bins themselves. If your bins are always full before the garbage is taken you can get a bigger one, but you will also have to pay more for the disposal.

You can't also dispose of larger items, so a lot of people just leave it by the garbage can thing. And since the trash gets taken via tubes to a centralised location no garbage trucks ever come to pick up the mountains of trash in our yard away leaving a lot of food for rats and crows who spread it around the yard.

author: Midan
text:
What trash system is used should be tailored to the density of the population. The Amsterdam trash system sounds like it makes great sense for dense urban areas, but as someone that has grown up and lived in the states in less dense neighborhoods it wouldn't make any sense. The cost of putting in underground bins wouldn't make any sense in a suburb with less dense population and when you have wheeled bins to wheel down your driveway. Bins are usually put at the curb or on a grassy median between the sidewalk and the street, and streets and sidewalks are generally wide so there is no real disruption.

I have also never really had a problem forgetting to put out the trash aside from when I first move in someplace and have to get into the routine. Nowadays it is even easier when you can just set a weekly reminder on your phone. I have never had to carry a bin once as I have always lived in places with a driveway. I know some people have issues with "Trash Pandas", but never had issues with that personally. That is probably because we have generally kept our trash bins in the garage to both prevent critters getting into them and also making it very convenient to drop your trash or recyclables in without going far or dealing with weather.

So if you're in a suburban area, wheeled bins and trash days make a lot of sense. If you're in an Urban area, communal bins that get picked up regularly make a lot of sense. The problems come when the system doesn't match the environment.

author: BoGy
text: we have an alike system here in Antwerp (Belgium) too ...  we have small "garbage-streets", where you go with your garbage, you swipe with your City-pass to open the appropriate collector, put in your trash (eg paper, plastics, glass, non-recyclable, ...).  Your city pass has credits on it, and it gets debited depending on Weight*type of rubbish... eg paper is a lot cheaper than non-recyclables, glass is free. It's very handy as you don't need to stack up garbage all week.  Though, we can still ORDER a thrash-day; when we want to dispose of big items like televisions, matrasses, furniture, ...  They come pick it up for free once a year and bring it to the recycling-park. Only if you have a lot of volume it'll cost you (over two cubic meters in volume; which is quite a lot)

author: Mostly Guesses
text: ... Sigh, trash pickup already works good just cram stuff outside my door into 2 big trashcans and then spend 2 minutes a week dragging it to curb - - - but this video shows apparently a block away a small hatch so guess one has to walk 5 minutes and then hand pick garbage out of a big bag one dragged and get hands dirty for 3 minutes - - -  plus most people don't live in apartments where density makes this possible, , , ,  Not to be pro-capitalist but the US has its system thru companies wanting the least cost but systems run by european govts could be HUGELY costly but they don't raise the garbage price - - just, until I see some numbers I bet this is a HUGE COST plus as already said takes 100x more time...  Sorry to be grumpy, but this video is soooo full of praise but I doubt it is warranted.... Now, biking in the Netherlands is genius, go Netherlands, but they aren't smart in all areas,,,,,  Trash and landfills take up just minutes a week and 1/millionth of our land acreage it is a 99.9999% good system sorta silly to focus on fixing it....  But great editing and good flow of video, I just doubt it...    PS.  I also dislike the vague talk, he is ""constantly""" picking up after animals (constantly=daily?? what), and that makes me doubt he's had '"Dozens"" of incidents with racoons - - - a real NUMBER like 3 times in 1 year is more convincing to us skeptics who have learned vagueness usually means lying on youtube  -- ...  Good channel in other areas, I am learning about N.  PPS, I could be totally wrong, but this video's vagueness leaves it open to suspect this is a terrible system being pushed by some brainwashed guy, so again more numbers would be great... Sorry for being buzzkill...

text:
Yes, kids do sometimes end up in these. Just hope there is no compactor on the inside of that specific one.

On a serious note. I actualy do know of 2 occasions where it happened. One was near my school in Arnhem. A newborn was put in one of these at night by a parent. Passer by's heard it cry and called the emergency number (112).
Another one was where kids were playing with it. And one opened it. Got in. And closed it. The friend opened it again and no more kid above ground.
112 was called and a quick 30mins later ish. He was fine.

The most important thing to not here is. It's difficult. But not impossible.

author: rest_in_prince1994_I_h8_trains
text: The household recycling system in Amsterdam is used in apartment blocks as well in Sweden. I remember back in the days when I lived on the 8th floor in an apartment block outside Stockholm, right outside my door next to the stairs in the floor hall, there was this huge pipe that goes down to the waste container for the garbage trucks to carry. On each floor this pipe has circular shaped metal cabinet  like door which you can open and then you just throw in your trash bags and when done you close it. It was so time saving and relieving considering the fact that you didn't have to go out when it was freezing cold and up and down. Unfortunately this system only exists for apartments and some townhouse areas.

author: leeluv96
text: Got problems with small rodents and other small animals? Go to Loranns website. Look for extra strength peppermint oil. DO NOT purchase oil for diffusing or "essence of" oils, only confectionery grade oil. Add a small amount to a dollar store utility spray bottle, fill with water. Dont think that more is better, it's not. Just a teaspoon to a full bottle is more than enough or a full dropper. Spray anywhere you don't want to see critters, reapply after rain, if spraying out side. Done. USE gloves. These oils are highly flammable. If you do nothing else, wash your hands several times after use. It's so strong I use goggles and a mask, you may not need them. For cats, use citrus, like orange peels. They hate it.

author: enzyme F
text:
Most places in the Netherlands still have trash days. And pretty much every municipality handles it differently. In some cities apartment blocks will have underground trash bins which you'll have to open with a card to prove that you actually live there. Family houses will have a garbage truck coming by every week. There is usually a set price that everyone has to pay monthly or yearly through taxes in these places.

In my perticular town there are garbage days like normal. You can choose the size of your container depending on your household. There is one green container for garden waste and fruit/vegetable waste, and one grey container for rest waste (restafval). In my town you pay per load. Every time the container is picked up, it will be scanned. At the end of the year you'll receive the bill from emptying the containers together with other local taxes.

We do have underground containers as well. Though they are reserved for things that can be recycled. There is one for cans, one for milk cartons, one for glass bottles, one for plastic packing materials. There is even one for diapers. There ar put together at convenient places and are free to use for everyone. That's just the small municipality/town where I live though. As I said, everyone handles it differently, and my example would be much less convenient and efficient in cities.

author: California Liberation Movement
text:
Underground containers would make a lot of sense in much of Honolulu. The sidewalks are so narrow that they often have to go into the street. In Chinatown, the produce markets are infamous for harboring rats. In places like Waikiki, the sidewalk trash bins must be emptied almost daily, because of the constant foot traffic. Finally, if they were installed in residential areas -- not likely -- one would not have to worry about someone going through your garbage for aluminum cans. A human being can cause as much of a mess as a raccoon, for sure.

Underground bins would be a costly investment, but it would solve many problems in that unique city.

Where I'm from (Berlin) the garbage truck drivers have a key for every single apartment building in the City. So we have big garbage bins in our backyard where everyone from our apartment is putting their garbage, and once a week the garbage guy enters into our backyard and takes out the big garbage bins.
The great thing is that you never have this smell of garbage when you're out on the street, besides the one day when the truck comes.

If they would do the same over in the US, I think it would end up deadly for many workers from the waste management, because every once in a while some resident would probably think that the waste guy is a housebreaker or some shit...

author: superafins
text: I've lived in two cities that are the absolute opposite of each other in terms of waste collection and management. In Guimarães, as in most of Portugal, you also have underground containers for each type of waste so you don't need to worry about garbage day; whereas in Salvador da Bahia, as in most of Brazil, not only is there no recycling of any kind (except for the odd local cooperative), but garbage trucks come by EVERY SINGLE DAY of the week and, in some neighbourhoods like mine, TWICE a day. That's because 1. residents will throw garbage out every day regardless, and 2. it's a very hot and humid place where organic waste will rot and smell in a matter of hours. But yeah, it's 2020 and garbage here still goes to landfills.

PE bottles (Bleach/milk etc.) are only collected in big supermarkets.
Aluminium can be recycled in big supermarkets or in collect point.
Glass can be recycled in collect point.

author: John Tedonneraipasmonnom
text:
Sorry to say, but Amsterdam isn't particularly advanced. It's Toronto and the other cities you mentioned that are a bit retarded.

In Barcelona, they use smart-technologies to map the garbage network and alert the city garbage collection unit when trash collectors are full. The result is that garbage trucks only come when necessary, it saves energy, time, money and you don't have to pay attention to a weird garbage calendar or be afraid of raccoons.

In Switzerland, we use the same kind of garbage bins / compactors than showed in the video at 1:15, except those are installed everywhere, not only in major cities. Even in the small mountain villages you don't have garbage days. In addition, we recycle a lot and have access to battery, glass, paper, compost and aluminium in every supermarket, in recycling centers and even sometimes at home.

Oh and btw, the Russian pencil story is complete bullshit. The graphite that compose pencils would create shortcuts and respiratory problems for the astronauts in a zero gravity configuration. Pencils were never used in space and the pressurized cartridges invented by Fisher were easily reproducible by Russians.

author: c182SkylaneRG
text: That's one thing that I miss from growing up in a small town with a local dump, now that I live in a small city with curbside garbage pickup: there was a lot LESS litter in the town where you had to bring your own trash to the dump. This isn't due to any "moral impetus" that the locals understand better or worse than anywhere else. It's because the night before trash day, and the morning of, is almost invariably windy, and the wind blows the recycling out of its bins and all down the sidewalk. Anything that's not blown out by the wind, might fall off the bin, or off an overloaded truck, when the garbage collector tries to dump your garbage into their truck, and is then left on the ground for you to pick up, or for the wind to blow away. There are all kinds of bottles, cans, and boxes in the woods beside and behind my house, which have blown down from my neighbors on trash day, and the pathway and bushes near my old apartment were FULL of letters and cups from the entire length of the street.

author: Matthieu Chirié
text:
Underground container are only a viable solution in dense area like amsterdam. In suburbs it would a pain in the ass for everyone. Althought quite usfull those containeer (the non recyclab one) need to be emptied once each two week to prevent hazard building into it. You know the reason why we don t just dump trash outside.

In cyties you have 10 to 15 houshold per building. If you have 3 building you can fill the underground container weekly. And as there is many it s worth it financialy for the city. For the resident you don t have to go far. And if it s full there is another neer.

However in suburbs, for the same space you have 3-4 household. So you would have 1 underground garbage container per huge street if you want to fill it weekly. Meaning people would have to walk long way with trash. If it s full, good luck reaching the next one. And the truck would make a long tour.

Or worst like in my town. They indeed put underground container in suburb. Anyone but the one living near take their car to bring trash bag to those. The city wanted to reduce polution and noise from garbage truck an now there is always 1 or 2 car going up and down the street. Sure no garbage day is enjoyable. Having to take trashbag in the car and take the car to bring it to container (i forget to tell they put it up hill so no. No way most of the people walk with their trash up there) is much less.

author: Sponge1310
text: In my town they started installing underground garbage containers about 2 years ago :) You can only open the ‘general’ trash ones with a special card, but the glass, plastic and paper ones are always open. It’s a nice system until you lose the damn card 😅 then you got to order a new one, pay €10 for it and you have to come pick it up yourself. The containers we have report automatically when they’re full iirc but have ran into full one a few times or find that someone put something in that got stuck rendering the thing unusable until cleared. I’m lucky to have two in my street, so I can usually go to the other one, but I’ve heard there are a few neighborhoods that only have one to serve quite a lot of houses and it’s a couple minute round trip for the people living furthest away... Probably still better than having your own personal bin that you have to remember to put out on the street and being stuck with the trash for another week at least if you forget....

author: Ralph Verwegen
text:
It's very nice that you introduce this concept to countries other than the Netherlands, but there are some very major drawbacks you fail to mention.
1. Kids have been known to mess about and get trapped in these.
2. There is such a thing as garbage day (when they come to empty them), and in some places you do end up worrying about them, because the containers fill up FAST. In my experience, they often fill up leading up to trash day and subsequently trash accumulates outside of the containers. So there is still garbage on the streets. In the Hague, they don't get emptied often enough, so we deal with flocks of seagulls ripping trash bags apart.
3. The containers system doesn't allow for the disposal of any oddly shaped garbage. If it doesn't fit in the little mouth section, you end up having to cut/break your trash apart. Any oddly shaped stuff usually ends up being stacked against the disposal unit. Again, trash accumulates on the streets.
4. The Netherlands doesn't have raccoons. It solves an issue we don't deal with. The containers do keep the sidewalks clear of big bins. That's a big plus. However, when it fails, the trash bags accumulating on the street are easy pickings for the pests that we DO have (Birds and rats)
5. The rotating mechanism has a tendency to fail. If gunk gets into the system (which it will, because its a trash disposal unit) or if enough people try to stuff their oddly shaped trash into the unit, it can get stuck. This means the lid no longer opens or closes. If that happens, NOBODY can use the unit anymore, and trash simply accumulates again.

I'm not saying that the alternatives for densely populated cities are much better, but there is a good reason why the majority of the Netherlands outside of densely populated areas uses bins. The containers are good because they trap the smell of waste and make it so there aren't large stacks of bags or rows of bins out on the small city streets. They also encourage the recycling. But they are not aimed controlling pests. If anything, they allow for pests to thrive.

text:
Here it's a mix of both. Trash (rest afval) is collected in underground bins.
But Paper, Plastic and Greens are still in containers that need to be put out every week.

Where I lived before it was all underground bins, but these can have problems. Half the time the Trash bin wouldn't work properly, as the card reader was dodgy. These card readers are needed, because people from other areas/towns would drive with their garbage to throw it away in our bins :| But not just the cardreaders were dodgy, the mechanism for these bins tended to brake quite often, jamming it shut. And as the recycle bins weren't as frequent as the trash ones....almost noone used them.

Now that I have large containers at this new house, recycling is easier and so I have started doing it more.

author: AlfredMoi
text:
It is an ongoing process but we will all have them because the sensor tells when the container is full and it can be collected anytime. Often people pay for half of the bill by the number of times they use the container except the recycle containers.


I miss that the uptown garbage bins are often underground also and bomb proof as bonus. Where I live the underground containers are sometimes incredibly deep and when the crane lifts one up, a spring loaded barrier comes up to prevent any one or pets falling in.


Now so many people dump garbage, for example when their chipcard or the system did not function or they had greater garbage, some containers are surrounded by a little garden. The square pot with all the nice plants is lifted high up in the air.


Towns have also connected deep bins to the containers, where for example broom sticks can be thrown in and that can be used by pedestrians that produce any waste. No complaints from me. I want one soon but people with little room for grey containers, like in high rise buildings, come first I reckon... It is like boom boom boom and the truck is back on its way in my street every day.

text: I'm from Amsterdam myself and these containers are the norm these days but garbage day is not yet unusual. My parents live in the center and they still have garbage day. My little brother still lives with them and one of his chores is putting it out the night before because they always come early in the morning. You don't use bins, you literally just put the binbags on the curb. When I grew up there were painted on blocks on the pavement that made them dedicated for garbage. So you couldn't just throw it out your front door, you had to bring it to the pick up point. It was never far though, usually just the corner of the street so the garbage truck only had to go down the length of a street and didn't have to worry about individual side streets.

author: CaptainDuckman
text:
Used to have communal containers (above ground at the time, 30 years ago), always problematic.
Were emptied once a week because the city had calculated the size based on how much the building would need in garbage volume per week, but neighbours and even businesses kept stuffing them with tons of waste so 2-3 days after collection day they'd be full already.
In the end the city capitulated and gave us individual bins per apartment, which made the central entranceway look and smell predictable.
we do have garbage days in Amsterdam, but every neighborhood has it on a different date, on that day you can throw out large things such as fridges and couches. next to those underground garbage bins

author: Rotcat
text: In the city I live in the Netherlands, Vlaardingen, 10 minutes near Rotterdam by Metro, we usually have both options, garbage bins aswell as those containers. What I've seen so far is that containers are more effective in dense neighborhoods (e.g. where flats or shared buildings - "boven/ onderwoningen" - are ) Houses that stand free usually still have garbage day, but since Vlaardingen (and mostly many other cities in the Netherlands) has a diverse mix of types of buildings in the same neighborhoods, its very common to see both (garbage day aswell as the containers). It is true, there are many containers in which you can throw your garbage away (that are maybe ~125meters (distance is mostly depended on the density and mix of the buildings of the neighborhood) away from your front door) before garbage day, if you dont have the garbage bin option (mostly common in the shared buildings & flats). I highly would recommend you to expand your view of the Netherlands and to just not only limit it to Amsterdam. Amsterdam is a city on itself. And most likely not comparable to the rest of the Netherlands in many facets of the life of a Dutchman

author: Marten
text:
Although I do agree that underground bins are an elegant solution for trash in dense neighborhoods, I think you make it sound more idyllic than it really is. There are two problems with underground bins I have seen.

Firstly. The emptying of the bins is pretty loud, especially in a city landscape where the metal clanging echoes off of the buildings. I've been woken up quite often by the emptying of the bins. And because the time slots aren't communicated to nearby residents, it's extra disruptive. A garbage truck picking up 'trash-panda bins' is a lot less noisy in my experience. (And we don't have raccoons in the NL, so that's not something we have to worry about a lot)

Secondly, the underground bins at hotspots generate a lot of stray trash ('zwerfafval'). Little bits of plastic or paper which blow away in the wind during depositing of trash. Or even worse, whenever a bin is full, people place their trash next to the bin. The trash next to it will eventually be picked up, but mostly the elements have several days to wreak havoc in it and spread bits and pieces all over the surrounding area.

Compared to other systems I've seen, it's a good system, but there ís room for improvement and I've heard of enough people protesting the placement of bins near their houses for the above reasons.

author: Kjeld Schouten
text:
The Netherlands is bigger than Amsterdam and those are not even the norm for all of Amsterdam.

They also have significant downsides:
- Being jammed (and residents being limited to a few locations only)
- Privacy complaints
- Broken keycards (and time to replace those)
- Computer Errors leading to broken containers
- Relatively small openings (A lot of people use big in-door garbage cans, instead of bi-daily walks to a container/bin)
- Sound complaints (they are quite loud)

Not saying they are bad, but they certainly aren't problem-free.

author: Trazyn
text: This is relatively new infrastructure. The government eventually wants to charge every household according to the weight of their garbage which can be measured with the passes that provide access to these underground containers. They've been running pilots in smaller municipalities for years. The problem is that applying a cost to disposing garbage in the container will lead to people simply disposing the garbage outside the container or start all kinds of cute fraudulent tricks, like disposing garbage in recycle containers or dumping it in nature. So the government hasn't figured this out quite yet and meanwhile the increased costs are felt in the increased municipal tax.

text:
I'm in Amsterdam and I love the underground garbage containers. There are containers for general waste at every corner of the street, plus containers for clothings, plastic, glass and paper.
No dirty containers on the balcony, no bags opened by rats, birds or cats. Streets look clean. No hassle with paying per bag, illegal dumpings or anything.
The very best isn't mentioned, every week it's "Grofvuil" (big waste), you're allowed to put old sofas, fridges, any big item on the street. Often people put items on the street in good condition, for neighbours to pick them up for 2nd hand use.

author: rolandet
text:
Let me give you some cons of these underground containers:
1. Standard sized garbage bags won't fit
2. If your pass/key doesn't work, you have to call to get that fixed, and on top of that, mostly pay for it.
3. If the city garbage company decides to close the nearest, (for whatever reason) you can go find the next one, and pray your key/card works.
4. There is no way to check what kind of garbage is thrown in
5. Prone to vandalism
6. People crawling (yeah i kid you not, it has happened)
7. Garbage being dumped next to the container. Now, we don't have trash pandas, but sea gulls do a pretty good job messing it all up (not to mention the rats)

Also, I noted that when our trash collector ROTEB went to these containers the saved manpower led them to use a 2 shift 6 days a week system where they come and collect anywhere from 7 AM to sometimes as late as 9 PM.


I just wish more people would call ROTEB when the container is full or malfunctioning as we don't have trash pandas but flying rats, aka seagulls and doves aplenty. Also, plenty of west-east oriented streets and winds from the west...

author: Metal Videos
text: there is a garbage day in the netherlands. maybe not in big cities. but residential do have normal garbage bins that get picked up by a garbage truck. believe the green bin every 2 weeks and the grey bin every week. so yeah big cities does it with underground bins. but not in small residentials. but where i live in a small village in the netherlands we do have a underground bin as well. but thats because i live in an apartment. normal houses all have standard containers. its simply not pracitcal in big cities. so they find a solution for it. we used to have big metal containers as wel for everybody to dumb their stuff in. but they get so cluttered with other people garbage that didnt live in the  buildings. so they decided to put in underground bins as well. we need a special card provided by the municipality to open the bin. so nobody else can put their stuff in. only the people that live in the building where the garbage bin is provided for. which i find a good solution.

author: P Constructor
text: I live in an appartement building in a small town. For the residual waste (grey waste) I got a card from the municipality for the card locked underground waste container near the entrance of the building. There is a weighing system inside that adds up your kilos residual waste and that you have to pay for. For all other waste you don’t have to pay. So it’s an incentive to recycle and have as little residual waste as possible. My empty glass bottles I have to deliver to another underground container for the whole neighborhood, you separate the glass in green, brown and colorless. The PMD waste (plastic, metal cans, drink cartons) is collected every fortnight in special plastic bags, you hang those bags off the ground on the posts of the streetlights, on special hooks so rodents and cats can’t reach them. The bags you can get free at your supermarket or at the municipality. And paper and carton is collected monthly, you can put it along the road in a plastic crate, a cardboard box or the blue kliko (roll container). I downloaded an app from the municipality that can be set up with a warning signal or message the night before or on collection day, so I won’t forget which waste is collected the next day.

author: J Groenveld
text: Well the concept isn't foreign to Canadians. A lot of areas have now removed individual mail boxes and now have them in a multiple box unit normally located in the middle of an area. Why don't we do this with trash too?

author: darkknight8139
text:
This is indeed really great. It is only common in the big cities (big for Dutch standards at least), like Amsterdam, Utrecht, Rotterdam and The Hague.

I live in Utrecht, only garden and food waste containers are emptied every week. I have to take all other garbage to the underground bin around the corner (literally).


Those underground bins in Amsterdam (2:50) are quite a lot bigger than they are in Utrecht, by the way. In the city centre, trash is picked up by boat over the canal.

author: rolandcombes
text: Here in Leiden (Netherlands), we used to have a similar problem a few years ago but with trash birds (seagulls). On trash day, they would descend on the bags and rip them to shreds, strewing garbage across the streets, while noisily quarreling amongst themselves. The gemeente (local government) of Leiden undertook a campaign to get people to start using seagull-proof yellow trash bags, which proved quite unsuccessful, going as far as launching an ad campaign depicting the seagulls as gangsters. In the end, the gemeente gave up and installed these underground trash collection points (one right outside the house we had just bought). Although the noise of the trash truck can be excessive, and we've pressured the gemeente to adjust the collection hours to later on in the day, it's such a relief not having to deal with the mess and noise of the seagulls.

author: Arshad Edlu
text: I’ve live in the Netherlands (in Eindhoven 🙄) for a few months and I love your videos. I think your channel has a lot of potential. Keep making great videos like this one

author: Linda #1961
text: Most places in The Netherlands still have garbage days. We do too AND have underground containers.

author: Lady AnT
text:
We still have garbage days in Helmond though (and other cities and villages).
One week grey, other week green and plastic and once a month paper. I`m used to it and have no problem with it.
But we have these systems in the city center and near big apartment buildings too.

author: mohit neupane
text:
Love your videos, I hope you never stop making these videos.
Im really interested in urban design and planning, can you recommend me some other channel or content sources like this channel.

author: Nova Verse
text: I´m sure this solution in our country would have been seen as another leftist extremist agenda?, is the phobia of simple solutions so delusional in The States?.

author: Jeff
text: While mostly true, I really loved the garbage truck tune in Udaipur India - it served more as an alarm clock than an alert that the garbage truck was coming, usually around 6 or 7am. And, it's a catchy tune! Kinda the same as never having to worry about "garbage day" - every day is garbage day. https://youtu.be/ISixWmyVyxs

author: GD CustoumZ
text: Wow amazing video 👍🏻

author: ZeNN
text: 2:18 Don't throw empty beer bottles in the glass container, bring them back to the supermarket. You get € 0,10 per bottle and they get recycled. Same goes for (1liter or more) softdrink bottles, which will 'earn' you € 0,25 a piece.

author: Mike Cane
text: Trash Pandas! LMAO.  Man, have they victimized me too!  Interesting video.  Thanks.

author: Hanneke N
text:
This is not quite as universal as you make it sound 🙂. These underground trash bins are used in denser neighborhoods, inner cities and for midrise appartment blocks and highrise flats. They can often be card-locked for use by the residents only.
The underground recycling bins for glass, paper and plastic (and sometimes for other things like metals or old clothes and shoes) are universal; they are placed in every neighborhood and near neighborhood stores and around shopping centers, for use by everyone.

The lower-density neighborhoods (as in suburbs and smaller towns) do tend to have the large plastic rolling bins of different colours for trash and recycling, that are picked up on an elaborate schedule in alternating weeks - everyone has a gray one for trash and a green or brown one for composting waste, then most municipalities have a third colour (blue, or gray with orange lids, or whatever) for a third type that differs by municipality: I have an orange-lid one for plastics, my father in a different town has a blue one for paper. His plastics get collected in plastic bags once every fortnight, our more windy town stopped doing that as the wind made a mess of those bags, so they switched to the third container. Our paper still gets picked up by volunteers for the sports clubs and churches, who get paid for the volume they collect. In dad's town they didn't consider that economically sensible, and the municipality collects the paper trash in the blue household bins.

But even in areas with separate household recycling bins you'll find the underground recycling bins, at the least near the neighborhood store (but often in more locations), for people who don't want to collect all these separate fractions at home for two weeks, and don't mind walking 50 meters to dispose of it, or taking the empties back when they go to the shop.
